commit_message:
Switch HTTP store to using requests

Previously the HTTP store was using httplib and specifically unverified
HTTPS connections to download data about images. By switching to using
requests, we will get several benefits:

1. Certificate verification when using HTTPS
2. Connection pooling when following redirects
3. Help handling redirects

Closes-bug: 1263067
Partial-bug: 1436082
Implements: blueprint http-store-on-requests

Co-Authored-By: Sabari Kumar Murugesan <smurugesan@vmware.com>

Change-Id: Ib114919c1e1361ba64fe9e8382e1a2c39dbb3271
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance_store refs/changes/07/168507/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import requests conn, resp, content_length = self._query(location, 'GET') except exceptions.BadStoreUri: raise redirects_followed = 0 while redirects_followed < MAX_REDIRECTS: loc = location.store_location conn = self._get_response(location, verb) # NOTE(sigmavirus24): If it was generally successful, break early if conn.status_code < 300: break self._check_store_uri(conn, loc) redirects_followed += 1 # NOTE(sigmavirus24): Close the response so we don't leak sockets conn.close() location = self._new_location(location, conn.headers['location']) else: resp = conn.raw content_length = int(resp.getheader('content-length', 0)) return (conn, resp, content_length) def _new_location(self, old_location, url): store_name = old_location.store_name store_class = old_location.store_location.__class__ image_id = old_location.image_id store_specs = old_location.store_specs return glance_store.location.Location(store_name, store_class, self.conf, url, image_id, store_specs) def _check_store_uri(self, conn, loc): # TODO(sigmavirus24): Make this a staticmethod if conn.status_code >= 400: if conn.status_code == httplib.NOT_FOUND: {'url': loc.path, 'status': conn.status_code}) if conn.is_redirect and conn.status_code not in (301, 302): reason = (_("The HTTP URL %(url)s attempted to redirect " "with an invalid %(status)s status code.") % {'url': loc.path, 'status': conn.status_code}) LOG.info(reason) raise exceptions.BadStoreUri(message=reason) def _handle_connection_error(self, error): # TODO(sigmavirus24): Make this a staticmethod exc = error.args[0] if any(isinstance(e, socket.gaierror) for e in exc.args): reason = _LE("Remote server where the image is present " "is unavailable.") LOG.error(reason) raise exceptions.RemoteServiceUnavailable(message=reason) else: reason = _("The HTTP URL is invalid.") LOG.info(reason) raise exceptions.BadStoreUri(message=reason) def _get_response(self, location, verb): loc = location.store_location if not hasattr(self, 'session'): self.session = requests.Session() try: return self.session.request(verb, loc.get_uri(), stream=True, allow_redirects=False) except requests.exceptions.ConnectionError as err: self._handle_connection_error(err)
deleted_lines: try: conn, resp, content_length = self._query(location, 'GET') except socket.error: reason = _LE("Remote server where the image is present " "is unavailable.") LOG.error(reason) raise exceptions.RemoteServiceUnavailable() except socket.error: reason = _("The HTTP URL is invalid.") LOG.info(reason) raise exceptions.BadStoreUri(message=reason) if depth > MAX_REDIRECTS: loc = location.store_location conn_class = self._get_conn_class(loc) conn = conn_class(loc.netloc) conn.request(verb, loc.path, "", {}) resp = conn.getresponse() if resp.status >= 400: if resp.status == httplib.NOT_FOUND: dict(url=loc.path, status=resp.status)) location_header = resp.getheader("location") if location_header: if resp.status not in (301, 302): reason = (_("The HTTP URL %(url)s attempted to redirect " "with an invalid %(status)s status code.") % dict(url=loc.path, status=resp.status)) LOG.info(reason) raise exceptions.BadStoreUri(message=reason) location_class = glance_store.location.Location new_loc = location_class(location.store_name, location.store_location.__class__, self.conf, uri=location_header, image_id=location.image_id, store_specs=location.store_specs) return self._query(new_loc, verb, depth + 1) content_length = int(resp.getheader('content-length', 0)) return (conn, resp, content_length) def _get_conn_class(self, loc): """ Returns connection class for accessing the resource. Useful for dependency injection and stubouts in testing... """ return {'http': httplib.HTTPConnection, 'https': httplib.HTTPSConnection}[loc.scheme]

added_lines: Deployment of Kolla on Bare Metal or Virtual Machine ====================================================.. NOTE:: Some commands below may require root (sudo) permissions (e.g. pip, apt-get).the latest available LTS kernel. The latest LTS kernel available is the wilyInstall git. To install Kolla tools and Python dependencies use:following information in the docker.service file in CentOS. If you do not set the MountFlags option correctly then Kolla-Ansible will fail to deploy the neutron-dhcp-agent container and throws APIError/HTTPError. After changing the service file you must reload and restart the docker service: # /lib/systemd/system/docker.service in CentOS # Run these commands to reload the daemon in CentOS # Ubuntu 14.04Libvirt is started by default on many operating systems. Run the following commands to check if libvirt is running. :: # Centos 7 systemctl status libvirtd.service # Ubuntu service libvirt-bin status Please disable libvirt on any machines that will be deployment targets. Only one copy of libvirt may be running at a time.On CentOS or RHEL systems, run the following command to check the available Ansible versions in the YUM repositories: :: yum --showduplicates list ansible On CentOS or RHEL systems, Ansible can installed using using:On DEB based systems, run the following command to check the available Ansible versions: :: apt-cache madison ansible or apt-cache policy ansible If the above command fails with an error saying docker has not started, run the following command to start the docker service. :: # Centos 7 systemctl start docker.service # Ubuntu sudo service docker start Run the following commands to create the docker group and to add the current user to the docker group. :: # Ubuntu 14.04 sudo groupadd docker sudo gpasswd -a ${USER} docker sudo service docker restart newgrp docker be communicating with an insecure registry. To enable insecure registry # Centos 7"/etc/sysconfig/docker". To rectify this problem in CentOS, set the contents of "/usr/lib/systemd/system/docker.service" to:To rectify this problem in Ubuntu, add the following to the variable DOCKER_OPTS in /etc/default/docker: :: DOCKER_OPTS="--insecure-registry 192.168.122.41:4000" # Ubuntu sudo service docker restart or the build process will fail. Run the following commands to check if the docker daemon is running: # Centos 7 systemctl status docker.service # Ubuntu sudo service docker statusRun kolla-build to build all the containers and to push them to the local registry (do not use the --push argument if you do not want to push the built containers to the local registry): 192.168.1.100 below is the IP address of the machine where the local registry is currently running. # Centos 7 kolla-build --registry 192.168.122.41:4000 --push # Ubuntu sudo kolla-build --base ubuntu --type source --threads 2 --registry 192.168.122.41:4000 --pushoperation if the first one fails. Re-running the above kolla-build command will rebuild all the failed containers. Run the following command to check the containers built by kolla-build. As of February 22 2016, kolla-build builds 112 containers. :: docker images # The following command should print 112 (as of February 22 2016) docker images | grep "192.168.122.41:4000" | wc -lor kolla_internal_address if kolla_external_address is same as kolla_internal_address (10.10.10.254 in this case). The login credentials for Horizon are admin/password.After successful deployment of OpenStack, running the following command can create an openrc file \/etc\/kolla\/admin-openrc.sh on the deploy node. Or view tools/openrc-example for an example of an openrc that may be used with the environment.Run the following commands to delete all running containers: :: sudo docker rm -f `docker ps -aq` or docker rm -f $(docker ps -a -q) Run the following command to delete all the containers built by kolla-build: :: sudo docker rmi -f $(docker images | grep -v registry | awk '{print $3}') Run the following commands to stop the registry container, delete it, and also to delete the local registry image: :: docker stop registry docker rm -v registry sudo docker rmi -f registry:2

commit_message:
Immutable parameters

Add a new "immutable" boolean field to the parameters section in a HOT
template.  A value of True will result in the engine rejecting
stack-updates that include changes to that parameter.  When not
specified in the template, "immutable" defaults to False to ensure
backwards compatibility with old templates.

blueprint: immutable-parameters
Change-Id: If17df0b97e96ff2a1926451634e4744d6c3e26f1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/72/256872/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: existing_params = environment.Environment({env_fmt.PARAMETERS: self.t.env.params}) for param in newstack.parameters: old_value = existing_params.params.get(param, None) new_value = newstack.parameters[param] updatable = newstack.parameters.params[param].updatable() if not updatable and old_value != new_value: self.state_set(self.UPDATE, self.FAILED, 'Parameter "%s" is not updatable' % param) return

commit_message:
Nova Neutron configuration now uses keystone v3 endpoint

Our current nova-neutron configuration does not work with
the latest puppet-nova. In particular, this patch[1].

This commit adds keystone v3 endpoints to the map and gets the
nova::network::neutron configuration to use them.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/puppet-nova/commit/d09868a59c451932d67c66101b725182d7066a14

Change-Id: Ifb8c23c81c665c2732fa5cd757760668b06a449a

commit_message:
add fernet tokens as optional token deployment method

* added recipe for fernet_tokens (recipes/_fernet_tokens.rb)
* moved pki setup to seperate recipe (recipes/_pki_tokens.rb)
* included fernet or pki tokens recipe based on auth strategy attibute
* adapted spec accordingly and added specs for fernet_tokens

Change-Id: I37af3e8e5d4b93e0de7f4ef2d999a05573eefc26

commit_message:
use bind_service instead of endpoints and cluster properly

* rabbitmq should use the bind_service attribute instead of the endpoint one,
  since these could be different
* adapted rabbitmq clustering attributes
* adapted rabbitmq clustering search to point to recipe instead of role

Depends-On: Iae7e302973805af3cb44be1b29d0e61e76eb0aa0
Implements: blueprint cookbook-refactoring
Change-Id: I08ed288e63422078d9beb36d14fd3c05f1cac435

added_lines: bind_mq = node['openstack']['bind_service']['mq'] if bind_mq['interface'] listen_address = address_for bind_mq['interface'] listen_address = bind_mq['host'] if node['rabbitmq']['ssl_port'] != bind_mq.port node.normal['rabbitmq']['ssl_port'] = bind_mq.port Chef::Log.error "Unable to listen on the port #{bind_mq.port} for RabbitMQ TCP, which is listened on by SSL!" node.normal['rabbitmq']['port'] = bind_mq.portnode.normal['rabbitmq']['address'] = listen_address node.normal['rabbitmq']['nodename'] = "#{user}@#{node['hostname']}" node.normal['rabbitmq']['clustering']['enable'] = node['openstack']['mq']['cluster'] node.normal['rabbitmq']['erlang_cookie'] = get_password 'service', 'rabbit_cookie' qs = "recipes:openstack-ops-messaging\\:\\:rabbitmq-server AND chef_environment:#{node.chef_environment}" node.normal['rabbitmq']['clustering']['cluster_nodes'] = search(:node, qs).map do |n| end
deleted_lines: rabbit_endpoint = node['openstack']['endpoints']['mq'] bind_interface = rabbit_endpoint.bind_interface if bind_interface listen_address = address_for bind_interface listen_address = rabbit_endpoint.host if node['rabbitmq']['ssl_port'] != rabbit_endpoint.port node.override['rabbitmq']['ssl_port'] = rabbit_endpoint.port Chef::Log.error 'Unable to listen on the port #{rabbit_endpoint.port} for RabbitMQ TCP, which is listened on by SSL!' node.override['rabbitmq']['port'] = rabbit_endpoint.portnode.override['rabbitmq']['address'] = listen_address node.override['rabbitmq']['cluster'] = node['openstack']['mq']['cluster'] node.override['rabbitmq']['erlang_cookie'] = get_password 'service', 'rabbit_cookie' qs = "roles:#{node['openstack']['mq']['server_role']} AND chef_environment:#{node.chef_environment}" node.override['rabbitmq']['cluster_disk_nodes'] = search(:node, qs).map do |n| end.sort

commit_message:
Switch to Futurist library for asynchronous execution and periodic tasks

This change switches the conductor to using Futurist library executor and
periodic tasks worker instead of oslo.service periodic tasks. This allows
running periodic tasks in parallel and relying on more standard interfaces
(futures, executors) when dealing with asynchronous execution.

A green thread executor is used instead of using an eventlet green pool
directly. The maximum number of workers is taken from the existing
workers_pool_size configuration option, and no tasks are allowed
to be enqueued to mimic the previous behaviour (might be lifted later).

The periodic tasks worker is using the same executor, and its main loop thread
is also running on it. For this reason minimum value for workers_pool_size
is now 3: periodic task main loop, keep alive thread and at least one thread for
other tasks. A special decorator for driver-periodic tasks is now deprecated,
as the generic decorator can be used there as well.

Closes-Bug: #1526277
Change-Id: I57bf7cebfb6db805b6c521bacfef2993b16ce1ee
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/20/264720/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import futurist from futurist import periodics from futurist import rejection help=_('The size of the workers greenthread pool. ' 'Note that 2 threads will be reserved by the conductor ' 'itself for handling heart beats and periodic tasks.')),class BaseConductorManager(object): super(BaseConductorManager, self).__init__() def init_host(self, admin_context=None): rejection_func = rejection.reject_when_reached( CONF.conductor.workers_pool_size) self._executor = futurist.GreenThreadPoolExecutor( max_workers=CONF.conductor.workers_pool_size, check_and_reject=rejection_func) """Executor for performing tasks async.""" # Collect driver-specific periodic tasks. # Conductor periodic tasks accept context argument, driver periodic # tasks accept this manager and context. self._periodic_task_callables = [] self._collect_periodic_tasks(self, (admin_context,)) for driver_obj in driver_factory.drivers().values(): self._collect_periodic_tasks(driver_obj, (self, admin_context)) self._collect_periodic_tasks(iface, (self, admin_context)) self._periodic_tasks = periodics.PeriodicWorker( self._periodic_task_callables, executor_factory=lambda: self._executor) # Start periodic tasks self._periodic_tasks_worker = self._executor.submit( self._periodic_tasks.start, allow_empty=True) self._periodic_tasks.stop() self._periodic_tasks.wait() self._executor.shutdown(wait=True) def _collect_periodic_tasks(self, obj, args): """Collect periodic tasks from a given object. Populates self._periodic_task_callables with tuples (callable, args, kwargs). :param obj: object containing periodic tasks as methods :param args: tuple with arguments to pass to every task """ for name, member in inspect.getmembers(obj): # TODO(dtantsur): move this check to a function in futurist if callable(member) and getattr(member, '_is_periodic', False): self._periodic_task_callables.append((member, args, {})) :returns: Future object. try: self._executor.submit(func, *args, **kwargs) except futurist.RejectedSubmission:
deleted_lines: from eventlet import greenpoolfrom oslo_service import periodic_task help=_('The size of the workers greenthread pool.')),class BaseConductorManager(periodic_task.PeriodicTasks): super(BaseConductorManager, self).__init__(CONF) def init_host(self): self._worker_pool = greenpool.GreenPool( size=CONF.conductor.workers_pool_size) """GreenPool of background workers for performing tasks async.""" # Collect driver-specific periodic tasks for driver_obj in driver_factory.drivers().values(): self._collect_periodic_tasks(driver_obj) self._collect_periodic_tasks(iface) def _collect_periodic_tasks(self, obj): for n, method in inspect.getmembers(obj, inspect.ismethod): if getattr(method, '_periodic_enabled', False): self.add_periodic_task(method) self._worker_pool.waitall() def periodic_tasks(self, context, raise_on_error=False): """Periodic tasks are run at pre-specified interval.""" return self.run_periodic_tasks(context, raise_on_error=raise_on_error) :returns: GreenThread object. if self._worker_pool.free(): return self._worker_pool.spawn(func, *args, **kwargs) else:

commit_message:
Send topic for DB get all entries methods

These methods will be called per tenant_id by the local
controllers when a local port from a new tenant on that
compute node is created.

Change-Id: I23cbe17c640eb5ae22837fa89bf3b25a2c32a3df

commit_message:
Extract function replace_api_version

To help with doing version replacement using version discovery,
extract the current copy-pasted code that does version replacement
using path to a function.

Change-Id: I8ecd0f7e350e3a373a12e34701e4c7528a9d3b54
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest-lib refs/changes/51/263451/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def replace_api_version(url, new_version): parts = urlparse.urlparse(url) path = "/" + new_version noversion_path = "/".join(parts.path.split("/")[2:]) if noversion_path != "": path += "/" + noversion_path return url.replace(parts.path, path) _base_url = replace_api_version(_base_url, filters['api_version']) _base_url = replace_api_version(_base_url, filters['api_version'])

commit_message:
Deployment with platform components

Acceptance tests:

Scenario is the same, component install difference only.

Add tests:
*	Deploy cluster with detached keystone, rabbitmq, database and Sahara.
*	Deploy cluster with detached keystone, rabbitmq, database and Murano.
*	Deploy cluster with detached keystone, rabbitmq, database and Ceilometer.

HUGE env (not always pass on deploy):
*	Deploy cluster with 3 controllers, 3 nodes with detached rabbitmq service and 3 nodes with detached db service.
	Note: this test requires at least 11 slaves.

Closes-Bug: #1537784
Change-Id: I243773851d980eee21372965f614d2d4a36388b6
(cherry picked from commit d70073a094da8f26ff52383fbccb4c5ab0e6bb58)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-qa refs/changes/38/284138/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2016 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import os from proboscis.asserts import assert_true from proboscis import test from proboscis import SkipTest from fuelweb_test.helpers.decorators import log_snapshot_after_test from fuelweb_test import settings from fuelweb_test.tests.base_test_case import SetupEnvironment from fuelweb_test.tests.base_test_case import TestBasic class BaseDeployPlatformComponents(TestBasic): """Shared methods for test scenarios with platform components deployment _install_plugins -> install all required plugins _enable_plugins -> enables these plugins _deploy_and_check -> verify_network, deploy, verify network, run OSTF """ def _install_plugins(self): for plugin_path in ( settings.SEPARATE_SERVICE_DB_PLUGIN_PATH, settings.SEPARATE_SERVICE_KEYSTONE_PLUGIN_PATH, settings.SEPARATE_SERVICE_RABBIT_PLUGIN_PATH ): self.env.admin_actions.upload_plugin(plugin=plugin_path) self.env.admin_actions.install_plugin( plugin_file_name=os.path.basename(plugin_path)) def _enable_plugins(self, cluster_id): plugin_names = [ 'detach-database', 'detach-keystone', 'detach-rabbitmq'] msg = "Plugin couldn't be enabled. Check plugin version. Test aborted" for plugin_name in plugin_names: assert_true( self.fuel_web.check_plugin_exists(cluster_id, plugin_name), msg) options = {'metadata/enabled': True} self.fuel_web.update_plugin_data(cluster_id, plugin_name, options) def __next_step(self): self.show_step(self.current_log_step + 1) def _deploy_and_check(self, cluster_id, timeout=7800): self.__next_step() self.fuel_web.verify_network(cluster_id) self.__next_step() self.fuel_web.deploy_cluster_wait(cluster_id, timeout=timeout) self.__next_step() self.fuel_web.verify_network(cluster_id) self.__next_step() self.fuel_web.run_ostf( cluster_id=cluster_id, test_sets=['smoke', 'sanity', 'ha'] ) self.__next_step() self.fuel_web.run_ostf( cluster_id=cluster_id, test_sets=['tests_platform'], ) @test(groups=["acceptance_deploy_platform_components"]) class TestsDeployPlatformComponents(BaseDeployPlatformComponents): """Deployment with platform components Test scenarios from acceptance scope. """ @test(depends_on=[SetupEnvironment.prepare_slaves_9], groups=["acceptance_deploy_platform_components_sahara"]) @log_snapshot_after_test def acceptance_deploy_platform_components_sahara(self): """Deploy cluster with detached keystone, rabbitmq, database and Sahara Scenario: 1. Install db, rabbitmq, keystone plugin on the master node. 2. Create Ubuntu, Neutron Vlan, Default storage, Sahara cluster. (Cinder, Swift, Glance) 3. Add 3 nodes with controller role. 4. Add 3 nodes with keystone, db, rabbitmq role. 5. Add 1 compute node. 6. Add 1 cinder node. 7. Run network verification. 8. Deploy changes. 9. Run network verification. 10. Run OSTF 'smoke', 'sanity', 'ha' tests. 11. Run OSTF platform tests. Duration 120m """ self.env.revert_snapshot("ready_with_9_slaves") self.show_step(1, initialize=True) self._install_plugins() self.show_step(2) cluster_id = self.fuel_web.create_cluster( name=self.__class__.__name__, mode=settings.DEPLOYMENT_MODE, settings={ "net_segment_type": settings.NEUTRON_SEGMENT['vlan'], "net_provider": 'neutron', 'sahara': True, }) self._enable_plugins(cluster_id=cluster_id) self.show_step(3) self.show_step(4) self.show_step(5) self.show_step(6) self.fuel_web.update_nodes( cluster_id, { 'slave-01': ['controller'], 'slave-02': ['controller'], 'slave-03': ['controller'], 'slave-04': ['standalone-database', 'standalone-keystone', 'standalone-rabbitmq'], 'slave-05': ['standalone-database', 'standalone-keystone', 'standalone-rabbitmq'], 'slave-06': ['standalone-database', 'standalone-keystone', 'standalone-rabbitmq'], 'slave-07': ['compute'], 'slave-08': ['cinder'] } ) self._deploy_and_check(cluster_id=cluster_id) # TODO: Test is disabled, until Murano plugin is not available. # TODO: Rework test for use with Murano plugin @test(depends_on=[SetupEnvironment.prepare_slaves_9], groups=["acceptance_deploy_platform_components_murano"], enabled=False) @log_snapshot_after_test def acceptance_deploy_platform_components_murano(self): """Deploy cluster with detached keystone, rabbitmq, database and Murano Scenario: 1. Install db, rabbitmq, keystone plugin on the master node. 2. Create Ubuntu, Neutron Vlan, Default storage, Sahara cluster. (Cinder, Swift, Glance) 3. Add 3 nodes with controller role. 4. Add 3 nodes with keystone, db, rabbitmq role. 5. Add 1 compute node. 6. Add 1 cinder node. 7. Run network verification. 8. Deploy changes. 9. Run network verification. 10. Run OSTF 'smoke', 'sanity', 'ha' tests. 11. Run OSTF platform tests. Duration 120m """ self.env.revert_snapshot("ready_with_9_slaves") self.show_step(1, initialize=True) self._install_plugins() self.show_step(2) cluster_id = self.fuel_web.create_cluster( name=self.__class__.__name__, mode=settings.DEPLOYMENT_MODE, settings={ "net_segment_type": settings.NEUTRON_SEGMENT['vlan'], "net_provider": 'neutron', 'murano': True, }) self._enable_plugins(cluster_id=cluster_id) self.show_step(3) self.show_step(4) self.show_step(5) self.show_step(6) self.fuel_web.update_nodes( cluster_id, { 'slave-01': ['controller'], 'slave-02': ['controller'], 'slave-03': ['controller'], 'slave-04': ['standalone-database', 'standalone-keystone', 'standalone-rabbitmq'], 'slave-05': ['standalone-database', 'standalone-keystone', 'standalone-rabbitmq'], 'slave-06': ['standalone-database', 'standalone-keystone', 'standalone-rabbitmq'], 'slave-07': ['compute'], 'slave-08': ['cinder'] } ) self._deploy_and_check(cluster_id=cluster_id) @test(depends_on=[SetupEnvironment.prepare_slaves_9], groups=["acceptance_deploy_platform_components_ceilometer"]) @log_snapshot_after_test def acceptance_deploy_platform_components_ceilometer(self): """Deploy cluster: detached keystone, rabbitmq, database, ceilometer Scenario: 1. Install db, rabbitmq, keystone plugin on the master node. 2. Create Ubuntu, Neutron Vlan, Ceph for volumes, images, Rados, Ceilometer cluster. 3. Add 3 nodes with controller+mongo role. 4. Add 3 nodes with keystone, db, rabbitmq role. 5. Add 1 compute node. 6. Add 2 ceph nodes. 7. Run network verification. 8. Deploy changes. 9. Run network verification. 10. Run OSTF 'smoke', 'sanity', 'ha' tests. 11. Run OSTF platform tests. Duration 120m """ self.env.revert_snapshot("ready_with_9_slaves") self.show_step(1, initialize=True) self._install_plugins() self.show_step(2) cluster_id = self.fuel_web.create_cluster( name=self.__class__.__name__, mode=settings.DEPLOYMENT_MODE, settings={ "net_segment_type": settings.NEUTRON_SEGMENT['vlan'], "net_provider": 'neutron', 'osd_pool_size': '2', # Replication factor 'ceilometer': True, 'volumes_ceph': True, 'images_ceph': True, }) self._enable_plugins(cluster_id=cluster_id) self.show_step(3) self.show_step(4) self.show_step(5) self.show_step(6) self.fuel_web.update_nodes( cluster_id, { 'slave-01': ['controller', 'mongo'], 'slave-02': ['controller', 'mongo'], 'slave-03': ['controller', 'mongo'], 'slave-04': ['standalone-database', 'standalone-keystone', 'standalone-rabbitmq'], 'slave-05': ['standalone-database', 'standalone-keystone', 'standalone-rabbitmq'], 'slave-06': ['standalone-database', 'standalone-keystone', 'standalone-rabbitmq'], 'slave-07': ['compute'], 'slave-08': ['ceph-osd'], 'slave-09': ['ceph-osd'], } ) self._deploy_and_check(cluster_id=cluster_id) @test(groups=["huge_separate_services"]) class TestsDeployPlatformComponentsHuge(BaseDeployPlatformComponents): """Deployment with platform components""" # TODO documentation @test(depends_on=[SetupEnvironment.prepare_slaves_9], groups=["huge_separate_rabbitmq_db"]) @log_snapshot_after_test def huge_separate_rabbitmq_db(self): """Deploy cluster with 3 controllers, 3 nodes with detached rabbitmq\ service and 3 nodes with detached db service. Scenario: 1. Install plugins on the master node 2. Create Ubuntu, Neutron Vlan, Default storage cluster 3. Add 3 nodes with controller role 4. Add 3 nodes with db role 5. Add 3 nodes with rabbitmq role 6. Add 1 compute node 7. Add 1 cinder node 8. Run network verification 9. Deploy changes 10. Run network verification 11. Run OSTF 'smoke', 'sanity', 'ha' tests. 12. Run OSTF platform tests. Duration 180m """ if settings.NODES_COUNT <= 12: raise SkipTest('Not enough nodes for test') self.env.revert_snapshot("ready_with_9_slaves") # Bootstrap additional nodes self.env.bootstrap_nodes(self.env.d_env.nodes().slaves[9:12], skip_timesync=True) self.show_step(1, initialize=True) self._install_plugins() self.show_step(2) cluster_id = self.fuel_web.create_cluster( name=self.__class__.__name__, mode=settings.DEPLOYMENT_MODE, settings={ "net_segment_type": settings.NEUTRON_SEGMENT['vlan'], "net_provider": 'neutron', }) self._enable_plugins(cluster_id=cluster_id) self.show_step(3) self.show_step(4) self.show_step(5) self.show_step(6) self.show_step(7) self.fuel_web.update_nodes( cluster_id, { 'slave-01': ['controller'], 'slave-02': ['controller'], 'slave-03': ['controller'], 'slave-04': ['standalone-database', 'standalone-keystone'], 'slave-05': ['standalone-database', 'standalone-keystone'], 'slave-06': ['standalone-database', 'standalone-keystone'], 'slave-07': ['standalone-rabbitmq'], 'slave-08': ['standalone-rabbitmq'], 'slave-09': ['standalone-rabbitmq'], 'slave-10': ['compute'], 'slave-11': ['cinder'] } ) self._deploy_and_check(cluster_id=cluster_id, timeout=60 * 60 * 3)

commit_message:
Tweaks for deployment on a pre-provisioned systems

* switch selinux to permissive mode
* show fuelmenu by default
* remove unused /etc/sysconfig/bootstrap_admin_node
* move debian-installer stuff to deployment script

Change-Id: I5d8a9776adc7b04d2cca06f9619f0b2f93c90181
Blueprint: separate-fuel-node-provisioning
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/38/283538/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # switch selinux to permissive mode setenforce 0 sed -i s/SELINUX=enforcing/SELINUX=permissive/g /etc/selinux/config || : showmenu=${showmenu:-'yes'}

subject: Implement Option for Two VIPs to separate API traffic
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-19 19:25:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/ef78710d9de76eb0e595083c798e9fc7001fb996', 'message': 'Implement Option for Two VIPs to separate API traffic

To improve security, operators have asked for two VIPs for
their cloud.

VIP 1 is the internal VIP that can reach internal and admin endpoints.
In addition, the internal VIP can also reach other internal services,
such as the database and message services.
VIP 2 is the external VIP that can only reach public endpoints.

With one VIP only, all services are reached at the same address.

To add a second VIP, this patch adds two new configuration parameters.

kolla_external_vip_address: is an IPv4 address to use for created VIP
kolla_external_vip_interface: is the network interface to use for VIP
In this scenario, the first VIP (the internal VIP), is defined by
the original parameters (kolla_internal address and network_interface).

When using two VIPs, the existing kolla_external_address parameter
should be/point to/resolve to the kolla_external_vip_address.

Closes-bug: 1535333

Change-Id: I5bfcefaf7899298455cdade8209c34324aebfecb
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-02-20 23:47:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/9359848121a3f2ad48c0dc0f4c23b54416bfe38e', 'message': 'Implement Option for Two VIPs to separate API traffic

commit_message:
Implement Option for Two VIPs to separate API traffic

To improve security, operators have asked for two VIPs for
their cloud.

VIP 1 is the internal VIP that can reach internal and admin endpoints.
In addition, the internal VIP can also reach other internal services,
such as the database and message services.
VIP 2 is the external VIP that can only reach public endpoints.

With one VIP only, all services are reached at the same address.

To add a second VIP, this patch adds two new configuration parameters.

kolla_external_vip_address: is an IPv4 address to use for created VIP
kolla_external_vip_interface: is the network interface to use for VIP
In this scenario, the first VIP (the internal VIP), is defined by
the original parameters (kolla_internal address and network_interface).

When using two VIPs, the existing kolla_external_address parameter
should be/point to/resolve to the kolla_external_vip_address.

Closes-bug: 1535333

Change-Id: I5bfcefaf7899298455cdade8209c34324aebfecb

It defaults to the # kolla_internal_address, allowing internal and external commiunication to # share the same address. Specify a kolla_external_vip_address to # separate internal and external requests between two VIPs. #kolla_external_vip_address: "{{ kolla_internal_address }}"#kolla_external_vip_interface: "{{ network_interface }}"

commit_message:
Read functional creds from clouds.yaml

devstack now writes out a clouds.yaml file which can be consumed to
find the credentials to use for a functional test run. Rather than
having each client write the code for pulling creds out of it
themselves, provide a default method which pulls the credentials out.
The method can still be overridden if the client wants to do something
additional, but there is really no real benefit in being different here.

This should allow us to delete code from several consumers.

Change-Id: Idaaea24795daf74977a133841960287da6fade3e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest-lib refs/changes/15/236715/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import os_client_config # Override this in child classes to specify a different env var to use # to find client utilities. CLIENT_ENV_KEY = 'OS_CLIENT_EXEC_DIR' self.creds = self._get_creds() def _get_creds(self, cloud='devstack-admin'): """Retrieves credentials to run functional tests Credentials are either read via os-client-config from the environment or from a config file ('clouds.yaml'). Environment variables override those from the config file. devstack produces a clouds.yaml with two named clouds - one named 'devstack' which has user privs and one named 'devstack-admin' which has admin privs. This function will default to getting the 'admin' credentials as that is what current consumers are doing. auth = self._get_cloud_config(cloud=cloud).get_auth_args() return dict( username=auth['username'], password=auth['password'], tenant_name=auth['project_name'], uri=auth['auth_url']) def _get_cloud_config(self, cloud='devstack-admin'): return os_client_config.OpenStackConfig().get_one_cloud(cloud=cloud) def _get_clients(self): """Method to initialize CLIClient object. This method can be overloaded in child test classes if there is something additional that the child test wants to accomplish. It should be used to initialize the CLIClient object with the appropriate credentials during the setUp() phase of tests. """ cli_dir = os.environ.get( self.CLIENT_ENV_KEY, os.path.join(os.path.abspath('.'), '.tox/functional/bin')) return base.CLIClient(cli_dir=cli_dir, **self.creds)

commit_message:
Fix/refactor policy check for cascade operations

The current code for policy check in cascade operations is using
@controller.filterprotected to receive the 'cascade' option and make
use of check_protection call, since the former creates the prep_info
dict, which is needed in the latter's call.

Several issues are involved in this code:
  1) prep_info is being created only for the root of the tree, when it
     needs to be recreated for every subproject, and then passed to
     their respective check_protection calls;
  2) Credentials are not being created for every project;
  3) @controller.filterprotected is only intended to annotate list
     calls.

1) is solved by recreating prep_info for every subproject; 2) is solved
by creating credentials info for every scope (subproject); while 3 is
solved by a refactoring where all the logic for policy enforcement in
cascade calls is put in a new annotation: @controller.cascadeprotected

Change-Id: I5ee5462922a4999c2c61d20c153734c208cfdef1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/45/283145/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @controller.cascadeprotected() def update_project(self, context, project_id, project): @controller.cascadeprotected() def delete_project(self, context, project_id):
deleted_lines: def _check_user_has_access_to_subtree(self, project_id, subtree, user_id): user_projects = self.assignment_api.list_projects_for_user(user_id) for project in subtree: if project not in user_projects: msg = _('Cannot perform cascade operation, because the user ' '%(u_id)s does not have access in the whole ' 'subtree of project %(p_id)s.') % {'u_id': user_id, 'p_id': project_id} raise exception.Forbidden(message=msg) def _check_tree_protection(self, context, protection_info, project_id, project=None): """Check protection for update project for tree API. The policy rule might want to inspect if the user have access for every project in the subtree. """ if 'cascade' in protection_info['filter_attr'] and project_id: subtree = self.resource_api.list_projects_in_subtree(project_id) user_id = self.get_auth_context(context).get('user_id') self._check_user_has_access_to_subtree(project_id, subtree, user_id) for project in subtree: self.check_protection(context, protection_info, project) @controller.filterprotected('cascade', callback=_check_tree_protection) @controller.protected() def update_project(self, context, filters, project_id, project): @controller.filterprotected('cascade', callback=_check_tree_protection) @controller.protected() def delete_project(self, context, filters, project_id):

commit_message:
Add update_access() interface to Quobyte driver

Implements the new driver interface for using update_access().

This is a new change set based on a previous one which was abandoned
due to merge issues (see change #275058). This updated change
contains all fixes and additions based on the previous comments.

Implements: blueprint update-access-quobyte

Change-Id: Id25103f9ef56383491dea6b914abdd89783671ef
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/36/281136/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 1.2 - Adds update_access() implementation and related methods DRIVER_VERSION = '1.2' def _fetch_existing_access(self, context, share): volume_uuid = self._resolve_volume_name( share['name'], self._get_project_name(context, share['project_id'])) result = self.rpc.call('getConfiguration', {}) if result is None: raise exception.QBException( "Could not retrieve Quobyte configuration data!") tenant_configs = result['tenant_configuration'] qb_access_list = [] for tc in tenant_configs: for va in tc['volume_access']: if va['volume_uuid'] == volume_uuid: a_type = 'rw' if va['read_only']: a_type = 'ro' qb_access_list.append({ 'access_to': va['restrict_to_network'], 'access_level': a_type, 'access_type': 'ip' }) return qb_access_list def _subtract_access_lists(self, minuend, subtrahend): sub_ip_list = [] sub_ip_list[:] = [{"to": s.get('access_to'), "type": s.get('access_type')} for s in subtrahend] return [r for r in minuend if ( {"to": r.get("access_to"), "type": r.get("access_type")} not in sub_ip_list)] def update_access(self, context, share, access_rules, add_rules=None, delete_rules=None, share_server=None): """Update access rules for given share. Two different cases are supported in here: 1. Recovery after error - 'access_rules' contains all access_rules, 'add_rules' and 'delete_rules' are None. Driver should apply all access rules for given share. 2. Adding/Deleting of several access rules - 'access_rules' contains all access_rules, 'add_rules' and 'delete_rules' contain rules which should be added/deleted. Driver can ignore rules in 'access_rules' and apply only rules from 'add_rules' and 'delete_rules'. :param context: Current context :param share: Share model with share data. :param access_rules: All access rules for given share :param add_rules: None or List of access rules which should be added access_rules already contains these rules. :param delete_rules: None or List of access rules which should be removed. access_rules doesn't contain these rules. :param share_server: None or Share server model :raises If all of the *_rules params are None the method raises an InvalidShareAccess exception """ if add_rules is not None or delete_rules is not None: # Handling access rule update if add_rules is not None: for a_rule in add_rules: self.allow_access(context, share, a_rule) if delete_rules is not None: for d_rule in delete_rules: self.deny_access(context, share, d_rule) else: if access_rules is None: raise exception.InvalidShareAccess( _("No access rules provided!")) else: # Handling access rule recovery existing_rules = self._fetch_existing_access(context, share) missing_rules = self._subtract_access_lists(access_rules, existing_rules) for a_rule in missing_rules: LOG.debug("Adding rule %s in recovery" % str(a_rule)) self.allow_access(context, share, a_rule) superfluous_rules = self._subtract_access_lists(existing_rules, access_rules) for d_rule in superfluous_rules: LOG.debug("Removing rule %s in recovery" % str(d_rule)) self.deny_access(context, share, d_rule)

added_lines: #!/bin/bash # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. bind_port() { echo "plugging veth $2 (Neutron port $1)..." # create a linux bridge br_name="br"${4:0:12} ip link show $br_name if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then echo "no bridge; create one" brctl addbr $br_name brctl setfd $br_name 0 brctl stp $br_name off ip link set $br_name up else echo "see bridge" fi # connect the veth outside to linux bridge brctl addif $br_name $2 ip link set $2 up } unbind_port() { echo "unplugging veth $1..." br_name="br"${3:0:12} brctl delif $br_name $2 ip link set $br_name down brctl delbr $br_name } case $1 in "bind") shift bind_port "$@" exit 0 ;; "unbind") shift unbind_port "$@" exit 0 ;; *) echo >&2 "$0: Invalid command $1." exit 1 ;; esac

commit_message:
Enable no-undefined

This rule enables the "no-undefined" eslint rule from eslint-config-openstack,
and corrects any linting errors found.

http://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-undefined

Change-Id: I2e7f00a36ef69ef4f8778cb2cf2a32a45e82fae6

commit_message:
Remove duplicate code in neutron extend_start.sh

Change-Id: I74aa68d809e9b38a605093abc4e2b8ca14335dee
Partial-Bug: #1546944
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/55/284055/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: if [[ ! -d "/var/log/kolla/neutron" ]]; then mkdir -p /var/log/kolla/neutron fi if [[ $(stat -c %a /var/log/kolla/neutron) != "755" ]]; then chmod 755 /var/log/kolla/neutron fi

subject: BGP Dynamic Routing: introduce BgpDrScheduler model
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-30 20:23:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/83f1bcb2dce814dfcd8fa5286c77a67d96f0d53e', 'message': '[WIP] BGP Dynamic Routing: introduce dragent scheduler model

This patch provides a new extension ("bgp_dragent_scheduler") with support for basic CRUD on
bgp_speaker and dr_agent bindings.

BgpSpeaker to BgpDrAgent association is 1-to-1. An admin user can only associate/disassociate
BgpSpeaker to/from a BgpDrAgent. There is also an autoscheduling feature that will assign a
BgpSpeaker to the first agent that asks for synchronization. Default scheduler class will only
assign non-assigned BgpSpeaker to a DrAgent.

Outstanding Items:
- Unit and API testcases
- RpcCallback implementation

Change-Id: Id305d9a583116e155441ac5979bf3f6aa6a8258b
Partially-Implements: blueprint bgp-dynamic-routing
Co-Authored-By: Ryan Tidwell <ryan.tidwell@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Jaume Devesa <devvesa@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: vikram.choudhary <vikram.choudhary@huawei.com>
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-08-10 12:48:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/c819312a4d20c63b9b32d44cec615f1e6551cb20', 'message': 'i[WIP] BGP Dynamic Routing: introduce dragent scheduler model

This patch implements autoscheduling of BGP speakers to
DR agent via a new extention called "bgp_dragent_scheduler".
In addition to this, basic CRUD support for binding bgp_speaker
and dr_agent is also implemented.

BGP Speaker to BGP DRAgent association is 1-to-1. An admin user
can only associate/disassociate BGP Speaker to/from a BGP DRAgent.
There is also an autoscheduling feature that will assign a BGP
Speaker to the first DRAgent that asks for synchronization.
Default scheduler class will only assign non-assigned BGP Speaker
to a BGP DRAgent.

Outstanding Items:
- Unit and API testcases

Change-Id: Id305d9a583116e155441ac5979bf3f6aa6a8258b
Partially-Implements: blueprint bgp-dynamic-routing

can only associate/disassociate BGP speaker to/from a BGP DRAgent.
Default scheduler class will only assign non-assigned BGP speaker
to a BGP DRAgent.

Outstanding Item:
 - Rescheduling BgpSpeaker to a new BgpDrAgent when the scheduled
   BgpDrAgent goes down

Change-Id: Id305d9a583116e155441ac5979bf3f6aa6a8258b
Partially-Implements: blueprint bgp-dynamic-routing
Co-Authored-By: Ryan Tidwell <ryan.tidwell@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Jaume Devesa <devvesa@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: vikram.choudhary <vikram.choudhary@huawei.com>
Co-Authored-By: Numan Siddique <nusiddiq@redhat.com>

'}, {'number': 21, 'created': '2015-09-26 07:10:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/debf3f09895c28538eeed97af66f5bef5b4df739', 'message': 'BGP Dynamic Routing: introduce BgpDrScheduler model

This patch implements a new extension called "bgp_dragentscheduler" which
does instant & auto scheuling of BgpSpeakers to an active BgpDrAgent. In
addition to this the patch also implements the basic CRUD requirement for
binding BgpSpeakers and BgpDrAgent.

BgpSpeaker to BgpDrAgent association can be 1-to-n. An admin user can only
associate/disassociate BgpSpeaker to/from a BgpDRAgent. Default scheduler
class will only assign non-assigned BgpSpeaker to an active BgpDrAgent.

Outstanding Item:
 - Rescheduling of a BgpSpeaker to a new BgpDrAgent, when the scheduled
   BgpDrAgent goes down.
 - Maximum number of BgpSpeaker which the BgpDrScheduler can schedule will
   depend upon the driver support. To realise this BgpDrScheduler need to
   query BgpDrAgent and get this information. Currenly, only 1:1 scheduling
   is realised. Need to change it for 1:N support.
 - Check for the existing test sufficiency and coverage.

Change-Id: Id305d9a583116e155441ac5979bf3f6aa6a8258b
Partially-Implements: blueprint bgp-dynamic-routing
Co-Authored-By: Ryan Tidwell <ryan.tidwell@hpe.com>
Co-Authored-By: Jaume Devesa <devvesa@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: vikram.choudhary <vikram.choudhary@huawei.com>
Co-Authored-By: Numan Siddique <nusiddiq@redhat.com>

'}, {'number': 35, 'created': '2016-01-03 13:46:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/b52bb8a970fb85beb086c9459b0c223dc48ff913', 'message': 'BGP Dynamic Routing: introduce BgpDrScheduler model

This patch implements a new extension called "bgp_dragentscheduler" which
does instant & auto scheuling of BgpSpeakers to an active BgpDrAgent. In
addition to this the patch also implements the basic CRUD requirement for
binding BgpSpeakers and BgpDrAgent.

BgpSpeaker to BgpDrAgent association can be 1-to-n. An admin user can only
associate/disassociate BgpSpeaker to/from a BgpDRAgent. Default scheduler
class will only assign non-assigned BgpSpeaker to an active BgpDrAgent.

Change-Id: Id305d9a583116e155441ac5979bf3f6aa6a8258b
Partially-Implements: blueprint bgp-dynamic-routing
Co-Authored-By: Ryan Tidwell <ryan.tidwell@hpe.com>
Co-Authored-By: Jaume Devesa <devvesa@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: vikram.choudhary <vikram.choudhary@huawei.com>
Co-Authored-By: Numan Siddique <nusiddiq@redhat.com>

'}, {'number': 38, 'created': '2016-01-12 23:39:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/d8240ed5dd10e7a26676c618674cffe2d5979112', 'message': 'BGP Dynamic Routing: introduce BgpDrScheduler model

This patch implements a new extension called "bgp_dragentscheduler" which
does instant & auto scheuling of BgpSpeakers to an active BgpDrAgent. In
addition to this the patch also implements the basic CRUD requirement for
binding BgpSpeakers and BgpDrAgent.

BgpSpeaker to BgpDrAgent association can be 1-to-n. An admin user can only
associate/disassociate BgpSpeaker to/from a BgpDRAgent. Default scheduler
class will only assign non-assigned BgpSpeaker to an active BgpDrAgent.

Outstanding Item:
 - Rescheduling of a BgpSpeaker to a new BgpDrAgent, when the scheduled
   BgpDrAgent goes down.
 - Maximum number of BgpSpeaker which the BgpDrScheduler can schedule will
   depend upon the driver support. To realise this BgpDrScheduler need to
   query BgpDrAgent and get this information. Currenly, only 1:1 scheduling
   is realised. Need to change it for 1:N support.
 - Check for the existing test sufficiency and coverage.

Change-Id: Id305d9a583116e155441ac5979bf3f6aa6a8258b

commit_message:
BGP Dynamic Routing: introduce BgpDrScheduler model

This patch implements a new extension called "bgp_dragentscheduler" which
does instant & auto scheuling of BgpSpeakers to an active BgpDrAgent. In
addition to this the patch also implements the basic CRUD requirement for
binding BgpSpeakers and BgpDrAgent.

BgpSpeaker to BgpDrAgent association can be 1-to-n. An admin user can only
associate/disassociate BgpSpeaker to/from a BgpDRAgent. Default scheduler
class will only assign non-scheduled BgpSpeaker to an active BgpDrAgent.

Partially-Implements: blueprint bgp-dynamic-routing
Co-Authored-By: Ryan Tidwell <ryan.tidwell@hpe.com>
Co-Authored-By: Jaume Devesa <devvesa@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: vikram.choudhary <vikram.choudhary@huawei.com>
Co-Authored-By: Numan Siddique <nusiddiq@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Id305d9a583116e155441ac5979bf3f6aa6a8258b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/07/207607/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2015 Huawei Technologies India Pvt. Ltd. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import abc import six import webob from neutron.api import extensions from neutron.api.v2 import base from neutron.api.v2 import resource from neutron.common import exceptions from neutron.extensions import agent from neutron.i18n import _LE from neutron.plugins.common import constants from neutron import manager from neutron import wsgi from oslo_log import log as logging LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) BGP_DR_INSTANCE = 'dr-instance' BGP_DR_INSTANCES = BGP_DR_INSTANCE + 's' BGP_DR_AGENT = 'dr-agent' BGP_DR_AGENTS = BGP_DR_AGENT + 's' class DrAgentInvalid(agent.AgentNotFound): message = _("DR agent %(id)s is invalid or has been disabled.") class DrAgentNotHostingBgpSpeaker(exceptions.NotFound): message = _("BGP speaker %(bgp speaker_id)s is not hosted " "by the DR agent %(agent_id)s.") # Vikram: Currently, only one BGP speaker could be associated # with one DrAgent. If we got to support multiple then need to # revisit below code. class DrAgentAssociationError(exceptions.Conflict): message = _("DR agent %(agent_id)s is already associated " "to a BGP speaker.") class BgpDynamicRoutingSchedulerController(wsgi.Controller): """Schedule BGP speakers for DrAgents""" def get_plugin(self): plugin = manager.NeutronManager.get_service_plugins().get( constants.BGP_SPEAKER) if not plugin: LOG.error(_LE('No plugin for BGP routing registered')) msg = _('The resource could not be found.') raise webob.exc.HTTPNotFound(msg) return plugin def index(self, request, **kwargs): plugin = self.get_plugin() return plugin.list_bgp_speaker_on_dragent( request.context, kwargs['agent_id']) def create(self, request, body, **kwargs): plugin = self.get_plugin() return plugin.add_bgp_speaker_to_dragent( request.context, kwargs['agent_id'], body['bgp_speaker_id']) def delete(self, request, id, **kwargs): plugin = self.get_plugin() return plugin.remove_bgp_speaker_from_dragent( request.context, kwargs['agent_id'], id) class BgpDynamicRoutingAgentController(wsgi.Controller): def get_plugin(self): plugin = manager.NeutronManager.get_service_plugins().get( constants.BGP_SPEAKER) if not plugin: LOG.error(_LE('No plugin for BGP routing registered')) msg = _LE('The resource could not be found.') raise webob.exc.HTTPNotFound(msg) return plugin def index(self, request, **kwargs): plugin = self.get_plugin() return plugin.list_dragent_hosting_bgp_speaker( request.context, kwargs['bgp_speaker_id']) class Bgp_dragentscheduler(extensions.ExtensionDescriptor): """Extension class supporting Dynamic Routing scheduler. """ @classmethod def get_name(cls): return "BGP Dynamic Routing Agent Scheduler" @classmethod def get_alias(cls): return "bgp_dragent_scheduler" @classmethod def get_description(cls): return "Schedules BGP speakers on DrAgent" @classmethod def get_updated(cls): return "2015-07-30T10:00:00-00:00" @classmethod def get_resources(cls): """Returns Ext Resources.""" exts = [] parent = dict(member_name="agent", collection_name="agents") controller = resource.Resource(BgpDynamicRoutingSchedulerController(), base.FAULT_MAP) exts.append(extensions.ResourceExtension(BGP_DR_INSTANCES, controller, parent)) parent = dict(member_name="bgp_speaker", collection_name="bgp/bgp-speakers") controller = resource.Resource(BgpDynamicRoutingAgentController(), base.FAULT_MAP) exts.append(extensions.ResourceExtension(BGP_DR_AGENTS, controller, parent)) return exts def get_extended_resources(self, version): return {} @six.add_metaclass(abc.ABCMeta) class BgpDynamicRoutingSchedulerPluginBase(object): """REST API to operate BGP dynamic routing agent scheduler. All the methods must be executed in admin context. """ @abc.abstractmethod def add_bgp_speaker_to_dragent(self, context, agent_id, speaker_id): pass @abc.abstractmethod def remove_bgp_speaker_from_dragent(self, context, agent_id, speaker_id): pass @abc.abstractmethod def list_dragent_hosting_bgp_speaker(self, context, speaker_id): pass @abc.abstractmethod def list_bgp_speaker_on_dragent(self, context, agent_id): pass

subject: Add processing of user defined VIPs by VIP assigning procedure
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-17 13:06:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web/commit/713040d83fa356df8608f6785c9c4260954fb22b', 'message': 'Add processing of user defined VIPs for assigning VIPs procedure

This patch implements processing of user supplied VIPs (already assigned)
for which namespace is defined. In case ip address of such VIP does not
belong to network where it is assigned the whole VIP allocation process
is interrupted as Nailgun must not make any assumptions regarding user
defined data.

Change-Id: I3051c0d6c31e6cf58fb3c6893b2c768292de4787
Blueprint: allow-any-vip
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-02-17 17:43:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web/commit/43c257b2e1d2330f96cb34e4c9b79b4090f8904d', 'message': "Add processing of user defined VIPs for assigning VIPs procedure

This patch implements processing of user supplied VIPs (already assigned).

In case VIP defined by user has non-empty namespace and check for
belonging to the network has not passed - error will be raised as
Nailgun cannot process user defined data in this situation. If user
defined VIP has empty namespace attribute it should be preserved as is
without check for belonging to the network.

In other cases (assuming the ip is within network's ranges)
VIP also should be preserved.

More details can be found in the related blueprint.

Change-Id: I3051c0d6c31e6cf58fb3c6893b2c768292de4787
Blueprint: allow-any-vip

commit_message:
Add processing of user defined VIPs by VIP assigning procedure

This patch implements processing of user supplied VIPs (already assigned).
User defined VIPs are returned w/o any additional checks.

More details can be found in attached blueprint.

Change-Id: I3051c0d6c31e6cf58fb3c6893b2c768292de4787
Blueprint: allow-any-vip
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/55/281255/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: return cluster_vip if already_assigned: ip_belongs_to_network = cls.check_ip_belongs_to_net( already_assigned.ip_addr, network) if ip_belongs_to_network: return already_assigned.ip_addr elif already_assigned.is_user_defined is True and \ already_assigned.namespace is not None: raise errors.IPDoesNotBelongToNetwork( "User defined VIP with id {0}, name '{1}', ip address {2} " "and namespace '{3}' does not belong to network '{4}'" .format(already_assigned.id, already_assigned.vip_name, already_assigned.ip_addr, already_assigned.namespace, network.name) ) assigned_vip = net_mgr.get_assigned_vip( nodegroup, net_group, vip_name) if assigned_vip is None: yield role, vip_info, assigned_vip.ip_addr
deleted_lines: return cluster_vip.ip_addr if already_assigned is not None and \ cls.check_ip_belongs_to_net(already_assigned, network): return already_assigned vip_addr = net_mgr.get_assigned_vip(nodegroup, net_group, vip_name) if vip_addr is None: yield role, vip_info, vip_addr

subject: allow **kwargs in identity.v3.token_client:V3TokenClient.auth()
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-22 17:55:02.000000000', 'files': ['tempest_lib/services/identity/v3/token_client.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest-lib/commit/b69d6a0e460610ec68cf950860365ea37d1d9fbf', 'message': 'allow **kwargs in identity.v3.token_client:V3TokenClient.auth()

Since auth() does not allow **kwargs, all the methods that call
get_token() have to explicitly pass all the arguments as keyword
arguments. This cause each test in tempest to have to explicitly
pass each variable from the credentials. If **kwargs are allowed
then all the tempest.conf options can be passed as **kwargs to
get_token() making the tests much easier to understand and it
easier to get a token.

Change-Id: I74cd2fc669340d056a877f997cd74d95465494f5
'}]
commit_message:
allow **kwargs in identity.v3.token_client:V3TokenClient.auth()

Since auth() does not allow **kwargs, all the methods that call
get_token() have to explicitly pass all the arguments as keyword
arguments. This cause each test in tempest to have to explicitly
pass each variable from the credentials. If **kwargs are allowed
then all the tempest.conf options can be passed as **kwargs to
get_token() making the tests much easier to understand and it
easier to get a token.

Change-Id: I74cd2fc669340d056a877f997cd74d95465494f5

commit_message:
SELinux support in 9.0 Fuel

This commit removes boot with disabled SELinux because since 9.0 Fuel
is perfect works in permissive mode. Also, it contains some cleanups
after separate project from the Fuel-main repo.

Change-Id: Ieb9cffa2ea2ba5507b86e298b471e43419ca0e4f
Closes-Bug: #1521154
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-virtualbox refs/changes/02/283302/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # default cmdline parameters passed to the kernel when boot the Fuel Master node cmdline="initrd=initrd.img net.ifnames=0 biosdevname=0 ks=hd:sr0:/ks.cfg ip=10.20.0.2::10.20.0.1:255.255.255.0:fuel.domain.tld:eth0:off::: dns1=10.20.0.1"
deleted_lines: # use defaults from the isolinux.cfg if script started from the GitHub cloned repositoy files. otherwise use same defaults defined here. cmdline="$(grep 'append initrd' ../iso/isolinux/isolinux.cfg -m1 2>/dev/null | sed -e 's/^[ ]*append[ ]*//')" cmdline="${cmdline:-initrd=initrd.img net.ifnames=0 biosdevname=0 ks=hd:sr0:/ks.cfg ip=10.20.0.2::10.20.0.1:255.255.255.0:fuel.domain.tld:eth0:off::: dns1=10.20.0.1 selinux=0}" # if you want to override the defaults feel free to uncomment and edit the line below # cmdline="initrd=initrd.img net.ifnames=0 biosdevname=0 ks=hd:sr0:/ks.cfg ip=10.20.0.2::10.20.0.1:255.255.255.0:fuel.domain.tld:eth0:off::: dns1=10.20.0.1 selinux=0"

commit_message:
Migrate tempest-lib code into new lib dir

This commit migrates all of the code from tempest-lib as of it's
current HEAD, 6ad0ce42c2791a28125d38b40e7dcddf32dbeed7. The only
changes made to the tempest-lib code is to update the imports and
other references to tempest_lib. Since in it's new home it should
be tempest.lib.

Partially implements bp tempest-lib-reintegration

Change-Id: Iadc1b61953a86fa9de34e285a0bb083b1ba06fa8

commit_message:
Ensure single ceph osd is weighted correctly

This patch ensures the OSD has a weight greater than 0 after deployment.
Ceph will not place data on an unweighted OSD and since there is
typically only one OSD for a devstack deployment, it makes the Ceph
cluster unusable.

As for why this behaviour changed recently, I don't have an answer.  But
generally ensuring a reasonable OSD weight is something we should be
doing anyway.

Closes-Bug: #1475333
Change-Id: Ied44ed81d890d25c43e563e844479924ac5f4a04
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/28/240328/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # for a single replica, ensure that the osd is weighted such that it will be used. if [[ $CEPH_REPLICAS -eq 1 ]]; then sudo ceph osd crush reweight osd.0 1 fi

commit_message:
Use more efficient mask_dict_password to mask password

The mask_dict_password method is added from oslo_utils 3.4.0, and it's
about five times faster than the mask_password method, so it's better
to use mask_dict_password instead of mask_password.

Change-Id: I6629ed1232f2e6f1c72b9f13b361e2f9e14b50a4

commit_message:
Improves logging

This patch change log string formatting approach,
moves it inside logging method to avoid formatting if
it is not needed for given log level

Change-Id: Ice73f2fc893701544cadc75bafd6833de0ae5d51

commit_message:
Set correct options path for bind9 agent

When using Red Hat systems and bind9 backend,
/etc/named/options.conf should be used so
this patch implements this change  to accomodate
the parameters used in the dns module.

Closes-Bug: #1534309
Change-Id: I546aceeb257954afe768bb1ee702a277ed0a2a5a

handle_signal, to make codes clean.

commit_message:
Don't useless fetch resources on update

Currently when updating resource in the database, we fetch the row many
times uselessly. This adds and uses an API to do less queries.

Change-Id: Ic50f8646fba6a578634e4e869ab5155756b0a1aa

commit_message:
Simplify event count by stack

The previous event count by stack used default sqlalchemy ORM count
method, which works fine but uses a subquery and loads all columns. We
can simplify it by using the func.count utility.

Change-Id: Ib3da569022cd4e13d0c7b13d98a4eb766cdb1a61

commit_message:
Revert isolation part of tests

Decided against this since it means that the isolation
of a test isn't up to the test itself but rather on
every other test that has ever been run cleaning
up after itself.  With the partitioning, as long
as we can come up with a unique ID, the test can
be isolated from all the others.

Change-Id: Iaa5c77540abfc0804787316e7e13725c4114cf8a

subject: Expose bug in cascade policy enforcement
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-22 17:06:03.000000000', 'files': ['keystone/tests/unit/test_v3_resource.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/5874d862ba95e45ca563e638fc745a4f880646f7', 'message': "Expose bug in cascade policy enforcement

Currently, in order to enforce policy in a project's subtree, it is
checked if the user has access to the whole subtree and if the policy
check passes by changing the scope for the policy check.

However, when changing the scope, the roles taken for the check should
also change accordingly.

This causes a bug where a user has enough permission to update/delete
on the root can cascade that operation to its subtree, even if it
should not be allowed with the actual roles assigned in the subtree.

This patch exposes the bug for both update and delete cascade
operations.

Change-Id: Ica1b891514fb291bd678ae2c49765828646563eb
"}]
commit_message:
Expose bug in cascade policy enforcement

Currently, in order to enforce policy in a project's subtree, it is
checked if the user has access to the whole subtree and if the policy
check passes by changing the scope for the policy check.

However, when changing the scope, the roles taken for the check should
also change accordingly.

This causes a bug where a user has enough permission to update/delete
on the root can cascade that operation to its subtree, even if it
should not be allowed with the actual roles assigned in the subtree.

This patch exposes the bug for both update and delete cascade
operations.

Change-Id: Ica1b891514fb291bd678ae2c49765828646563eb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/68/283168/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @test_utils.wip('Bug in cascade operations') def test_update_project_tree_cascade_without_enough_permissions(self): projects = self._create_projects_hierarchy(hierarchy_size=3) root_id = projects[0]['project']['id'] # Assign an inherited assignment with a random role role = unit.new_role_ref() role = self.role_api.create_role(role['id'], role) assignment_url = self.build_role_assignment_link( role_id=role['id'], user_id=self.user_id, project_id=root_id, inherited_to_projects=True) self.put(assignment_url) # Assign admin role only on the root project assignment_url = self.build_role_assignment_link( role_id=self.role_id, user_id=self.user_id, project_id=root_id) self.put(assignment_url) # The API call to disable the hierarchy on cascade should fail, since # the user does not have admin on all projects, which is required in # policy self.patch( '/projects/%(project_id)s?cascade' % {'project_id': root_id}, body={'project': {'enabled': False}}, expected_status=exception.Forbidden.code) @test_utils.wip('Bug in cascade operations') def test_delete_project_tree_cascade_without_enough_permissions(self): projects = self._create_projects_hierarchy(hierarchy_size=3) root_id = projects[0]['project']['id'] # Assign an inherited assignment with a random role role = unit.new_role_ref() role = self.role_api.create_role(role['id'], role) assignment_url = self.build_role_assignment_link( role_id=role['id'], user_id=self.user_id, project_id=root_id, inherited_to_projects=True) self.put(assignment_url) # Assign inherited admin role on the root project assignment_url = self.build_role_assignment_link( role_id=self.role_id, user_id=self.user_id, project_id=root_id, inherited_to_projects=True) self.put(assignment_url) # Disable all projects self.patch( '/projects/%(project_id)s?cascade' % {'project_id': root_id}, body={'project': {'enabled': False}}) # Remove admin inherited role assingment and add only on the root self.delete(assignment_url) assignment_url = self.build_role_assignment_link( role_id=role['id'], user_id=self.user_id, project_id=root_id) self.put(assignment_url) # Even though all projects in the hierarchy are disabled, the API call # to delete the hierarchy on cascade should fail, since the user does # not have admin on all projects, which is required in policy self.delete( '/projects/%(project_id)s?cascade' % {'project_id': root_id}, expected_status=exception.Forbidden.code)

commit_message:
Fix service-list filter

Currently cinder service list --host=<hostname> will not show any
results for the volume services. This is because the volume-services
append an internal pool name to the hostname and as a result there
won't be a match for the specific filter. This patch fixes the
incorrect work of service-list with '--host' argument. Also it filters
data on the DB side to improve performance.

APIImpact
Closes-Bug: 1530144
Change-Id: I21775106693176ca128dbfd9db0d43cfc58de00a
Depends-On: I4044ab15078ecf54447e1c6e67c27fc8d7c9d6f7

commit_message:
Now using the new bind_address method from common

* cleaned up endpoint and bind interface attributes
* moved compute-ec2 attribute to compute-ec2-api
  for clearness on which is public internal or admin

Change-Id: I16fb99ea2f865ea95b653c68fd5a42f15d039439

commit_message:
Put py34 first in the env order of tox

To solve the problem of "db type could
not be determined" on py34 we have to run first the py34 env to, then, run
py27. This patch puts py34 first on the tox.ini list of envs to avoid this
problem to happen.

"Closes-Bug: #1533919"
Change-Id: Ib247b4000d9c1d906ef55fa2b5cc990cf1120850
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient refs/changes/61/266761/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: envlist = py34,py27,pypy,pep8

commit_message:
Make ZaqarEventSinkTest more lenient

We don't have strong ordering of events enforced, so there is no need to
test that events arrive in order, and it actually make tests fail
intermittently. Let's relax that check.

Change-Id: I73be763df5ddf863e29df1b9ac8792f05700e006
Closes-Bug: #1549264
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/00/284100/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: statuses.sort() ['COMPLETE', 'COMPLETE', 'IN_PROGRESS', 'IN_PROGRESS'], statuses)

commit_message:
Change info printings for pub-sub to debug

The printings were causing the controller screen to be full
of useless messages, this moves them to debug

Add OpenstackClient plugin for cluster policy show

This change implements the "openstack cluster policy show" command
  Based on the existing senlin command: senlin policy-show

Change-Id: I2f650d1c101ed7317a25fdaca8a025683e8bb4ea
Blueprint: senlin-support-python-openstackclient
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-senlinclient refs/changes/17/282817/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from cliff import show from openstack import exceptions as sdk_exc from openstackclient.common import exceptions as excfrom senlinclient.common import utils as senlin_utils class ShowPolicy(show.ShowOne): """Show the policy details.""" log = logging.getLogger(__name__ + ".ShowPolicy") def get_parser(self, prog_name): parser = super(ShowPolicy, self).get_parser(prog_name) parser.add_argument( 'policy', metavar='<policy>', help=_('Name of the policy to be updated') ) return parser def take_action(self, parsed_args): self.log.debug("take_action(%s)", parsed_args) senlin_client = self.app.client_manager.clustering return _show_policy(senlin_client, policy_id=parsed_args.policy) def _show_policy(senlin_client, policy_id): try: policy = senlin_client.get_policy(policy_id) except sdk_exc.ResourceNotFound: raise exc.CommandError(_('Policy not found: %s') % policy_id) formatters = { 'spec': senlin_utils.json_formatter } columns = [ 'created_at', 'data', 'domain', 'id', 'name', 'project', 'spec', 'type', 'updated_at', 'user' ] return columns, utils.get_dict_properties(policy.to_dict(), columns, formatters=formatters)

commit_message:
Implements: blueprint entity-graph-change-notifications

Change-Id: I18dfa33434c7c1b707b6e6d2a3a98947ae618322
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/vitrage refs/changes/58/283758/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_log import log as loggingfrom vitrage.graph import Edge from vitrage.graph import Notificationfrom vitrage.graph import VertexLOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) def test_graph_callbacks(self): g = create_graph('test_graph_callbacks') self.callback_counter = 0 def callback(event, pre_event_item, current_item): LOG.info('called with: event ' + str(event) + ' pre_event_item ' + str(pre_event_item) + ' current_item ' + str(current_item)) self.assertIsNotNone(event) if event == Notification.ADD_VERTEX: self.assertIsNone( pre_event_item, event + ' pre_event_item should be None') self.assertIsNotNone( current_item, event + ' current_item is empty') self.assertTrue( isinstance(current_item, Vertex), event + ' current_item type incorrect') elif event == Notification.UPDATE_VERTEX: self.assertIsNotNone( pre_event_item, event + ' pre_event_item is empty') self.assertIsNotNone( current_item, event + ' current_item is empty') self.assertTrue( isinstance(pre_event_item, Vertex), event + ' pre_event_item type incorrect') self.assertTrue( isinstance(current_item, Vertex), event + ' current_item type incorrect') elif event == Notification.ADD_EDGE: self.assertIsNone( pre_event_item, event + ' pre_event_item should be None') self.assertIsNotNone( current_item, event + ' current_item is empty') self.assertTrue( isinstance(current_item, Edge), event + ' current_item type incorrect') elif event == Notification.UPDATE_EDGE: self.assertIsNotNone( pre_event_item, event + ' pre_event_item is empty') self.assertIsNotNone( current_item, event + ' current_item is empty') self.assertTrue( isinstance(pre_event_item, Edge), event + ' pre_event_item type incorrect') self.assertTrue( isinstance(current_item, Edge), event + ' current_item type incorrect') else: self.assertEqual(True, False, event + ' Event is unknown') self.callback_counter += 1 # Check there is no notification without subscribing g.add_vertex(v_alarm) self.assertEqual( 0, self.callback_counter, 'Got notification, but add_vertex notification is not registered') # subscribe g.subscribe(Notification.ADD_VERTEX, callback) g.subscribe(Notification.UPDATE_VERTEX, callback) g.subscribe(Notification.ADD_EDGE, callback) g.subscribe(Notification.UPDATE_EDGE, callback) # These actions will trigger callbacks: g.add_vertex(v_node) g.add_vertex(v_host) g.add_edge(e_node_to_host) updated_vertex = g.get_vertex(v_host.vertex_id) updated_vertex[VProps.CATEGORY] = ALARM g.update_vertex(updated_vertex) updated_edge = g.get_edge(e_node_to_host.source_id, e_node_to_host.target_id, e_node_to_host.label) updated_edge['ZIG'] = 'ZAG' g.update_edge(updated_edge) self.assertEqual(5, self.callback_counter, 'Not all notifications received')

commit_message:
Increase the default max_overflow value

It turned out that distribution of WSGI requests between forks is not
even when eventlet is used, which can cause pool timeout issues under
load, while there are idle workers with open DB connections, which
should have served these HTTP requests.

The default max_overflow value should be increased to allow DB oriented
services (mostly APIs) handle spikes in number of concurrent requests
trying to use a DB.

At the same time, the default number of greenlets is decreased:

 I65b40b9906b75146a0085bbe168f1e6bcae82f21

which effectively causes a particular worker to stop accepting new
requests it has no resources (DB connections) to handle and allow
other forks accept()'ing on the same FD to proceed.

Testing was performed using this script:

  https://gist.github.com/zzzeek/c69138fd0d0b3e553a1f

With 100 greenthreads in the pool, 50 DB connections allowed overflow
no pool timeout issues were seen with up to 500 concurrent requests
done by ab, while current default values (1000/10) could not handle
even 100 concurrent requests.

See this ML thread for details:

  http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-December/082717.html

DocImpact

This change potentially increases the number of connections open to the
RDBMS server. If you start seeing "too many connections" errors, please
check these settings and adjust them appropriately:

https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.5/en/server-system-variables.html#sysvar_max_connections
http://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/runtime-config-connection.html#GUC-MAX-CONNECTIONS

Closes-Bug: #1535375

Change-Id: I2e9c2a71d8231e0dfbefc6293ad319e1e459beec

commit_message:
Fix conductor to *really* pass the Spec obj

So, we missed the fact that we were blocking the conductor API to pass
the RequestSpec object down to the wire because we arbitrarely set
the argument to None anyway.

Change-Id: I6f3dfd6acaf51b2aacaa61973b47f60dad87159e

commit_message:
Improve status table CSS.

This adds several small improvements to the CSS for the status table
on the homepage. The table itself is now seamlessly enclosed in the
outer panel, and the bar chart column is now capped at 300px with
empty space to the side removed. Additionally, the chart is hidden
on small and extra-small layouts to prevent the table from overflowing
when there isn't enough space for it to fit.

Change-Id: Id17419e381d3a4e18caf10c4a2c96ad152c28963
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-health refs/changes/63/283763/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: table.status-table { width: 100%; overflow: auto; thead { white-space: nowrap; th[sort-field="name"] { width: 100%; } th:not(:first-child) { min-width: 75px; } th:last-child { @extend .hidden-xs; @extend .hidden-sm; min-width: 300px; max-width: 300px; } } tbody { td:last-child { @extend .hidden-xs; @extend .hidden-sm; } } }
