commit_message:
describe ovsdb monitor mechanism for DragonFlow

Change-Id: I9ec5ad052f09b3f01ea7ecd3ed0665bcdfc20e2f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/dragonflow refs/changes/32/274332/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============== OVSDB Monitor =============== This blueprint describe the addition of OVSDB monitor support for Dragonflow. It implements the lightweight OVSDB driver which based on the OVSDB monitor\notification mechanism, it solves the performance problem for Dragonflow to fetch vm ports/interfaces info from OVSDB. =================== Problem Description =================== In current Dragonflow implementation of fetch OVSDB data, Dragonflow will start a loop to detect the add\update\delete for logical ports, for example after Dragonflow finds a new logical port, it will establish a socket channel to OVSDB, fetch many data from some OVSDB tables(Bridge\Port\Interface Table) and find several useful info(ofport\chassis id) for the new logical port. There are some performance problems for above implementation: 1.The loop will consume many server resources because it will pull large amount data from DB cluster and do the comparison with the local cache frequently; 2.For each new logical port, Dragonflow will create a socket channel to fetch data from OVSDB, if we create many new logical ports in the future or even in a very short time, it will consume the server resources further; 3.For each session between Dragonflow and OVSDB for a new logical port, it will fetch many unnecessary data from many OVSDB tables; ==================== Solution Description ==================== We bring in OVSDB monitor\notification mechanism which has detail description in OVSDB protocol rfc(https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7047#section-4.1.5): We have Dragonflow and open vswitch on the same server, when OVS start up, OVSDB will listen on port 6640, while when Dragonflow start up, OVSDB driver will attempt to connect the OVSDB and subscribe the data to OVSDB server which it is interested in, the details show below: 1.OVSDB server start up and listen on port 6640 and Dragonflow start up while the OVSDB driver try to connect to OVSDB server as OVSDB client with tcp:127.0.0.1:6640; 2.When OVSDB driver establish the channel with OVSDB server, OVSDB driver send the OVSDB monitor command with below jsonrpc content: method:monitor params:[<db-name>,<json-value>,<monitor-requests>] id:nonnull-json-value In our solution, we only monitor the OVSDB Interface Table, so OVSDB driver will send the monitor Interface table jsonrpc message to OVSDB server; 3.When OVSDB server receive the monitor message sent by OVSDB driver, it will send a reply message which contains all the interfaces detail info (if it has) back to OVSDB driver; 4.OVSDB driver receives and decodes the monitor reply message, it will map each interface info to different type events(bridge online, vm online, tunnel port online, patch port online), OVSDB driver will send these events to other Dragonflow modules which are interested in; 5.When tenant boot a vm on the host and add the vm port to the OVS bridge, OVSDB server will send a notification to OVSDB driver according to the update of OVS Interface Table, the notification will only contain the new vm interface detail info, and after OVSDB driver receive the notification it will do the same work as step 4; 6.When tenant shutdown a vm on the host and delete the vm port from the OVS bridge, OVSDB server will send a notification to OVSDB driver according to the update of OVS Interface Table, the notification will only contain the delete vm interface detail info, and after OVSDB driver receive the notification it will do the same work as step 4. If we restart Dragonflow process or restart the OVSDB, Dragonflow OVSDB driver will reconnect to OVSDB server, so step1 to 6 will be executed again. ==================== Event Classification ==================== We could judge the event type according to the fields content in the monitor reply or table change notification, if you want to see the detail content in the message, you can execute the command on the OVS(OVSDB monitor Interface -v) , the detail judgement fields show below: Bridge online: type internal name Br-int\br-tun\br-ex Vm online: Iface-id 4aa64e21-d9d6-497e-bfa9-cf6dbb574054 name tapxxx Tunnel port online Remote_ip 10.10.10.10 name dfxxx type Vxlan\gre\geneve Patch port online type patch options Peer=<peer port name> ========= Conclusion ========= Our solution provides a lightweight OVSDB driver functionality which implements the OVSDB data monitor and synchronize, remove the Dragonflow loop process, maintain only one socket channel and transfer less data.

commit_message:
Operations on reflected entities

Now it is possible to get/set reflected property value on particular object
(or null for static property).

Also it is possible to invoke instance/static reflected methods.

Change-Id: If25c28712160d9a6aa8947b9173f8987ce76caec

commit_message:
Fixed 'workflow_name' key error

when workflow execution is created by workflow_id
'workflow_name' key error was raised. Now 'workflow_name'
is extracted from dictionary using get() function.

Change-Id: I5a648742b2653818d3bc4d4025ce1fe0b73a2d24
Closes-bug: #1549047

commit_message:
Move backup and restore file in 1 file

Change-Id: I9b7212bec963feb56c83b7d93405e566ae73dcba
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-octane refs/changes/47/282647/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import contextlib import logging import os import tarfile import tempfile from cliff import command from octane.handlers import backup_restore from octane.util import encryption LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) def _restore(io_arch, archivators): with contextlib.closing(tarfile.open(fileobj=io_arch)) as archive: archivators = [cls(archive) for cls in archivators] for archivator in archivators: archivator.pre_restore_check() for archivator in archivators: archivator.restore() def restore(path_to_backup, archivators, password): if password: with contextlib.closing(tempfile.TemporaryFile()) as temp_file: with open(path_to_backup) as input_io: encryption.decrypt_io(input_io, temp_file, password) temp_file.seek(0) _restore(temp_file, archivators) else: with open(path_to_backup) as io_file: _restore(io_file, archivators) class BaseRestoreCommand(command.Command): archivators = None encrypted = False def get_parser(self, *args, **kwargs): parser = super(BaseRestoreCommand, self).get_parser(*args, **kwargs) parser.add_argument( "--from", type=str, action="store", dest="path", required=True, help="path to backup file") if self.encrypted: parser.add_argument( "--password", type=str, dest="password", help="") parser.add_argument( '--encrypted', dest='encrypted', action='store_true') parser.add_argument( '--not-encrypted', dest='encrypted', action='store_false') parser.set_defaults(encrypted=True) return parser def take_action(self, parsed_args): assert self.archivators password = None if self.encrypted: if parsed_args.encrypted != bool(parsed_args.password): raise AssertionError("Password required for encrypted backup") if parsed_args.encrypted: password = parsed_args.password if not os.path.isfile(parsed_args.path): raise ValueError("Invalid path to backup file") restore(parsed_args.path, self.archivators, password) class RestoreCommand(BaseRestoreCommand): archivators = backup_restore.ARCHIVATORS encrypted = True class RestoreRepoCommand(BaseRestoreCommand): archivators = backup_restore.REPO_ARCHIVATORS

commit_message:
Allow vncproxy to work with ssl enabled

Right now our vncproxy settings are hard-coded to http and the
non-ssl port.  This change adds a vncproxy entry to the endpoint
map and uses those values to configure the proxy correctly on
compute nodes.  This is sufficient to get it working in my
environment with ssl enabled.

Change-Id: I9d69b088eef4700959b33c7e0eb44932949d7b71

commit_message:
invert the order of endpoint and bind_service attributes

* endpoint type (admin, internal, public) and service (identitiy, network etc.)
  was switched during refactoring, this patch reverts this unintended switching
* edited bind_service service type from public,internal,admin to 'all'
  for default binding to just one service
* use bind_address method from common

Change-Id: I4f97b659361dabd7fac216305d2aad2f1bb98f51
Depends-On: Iec485deaf415e4187a323435cce2b6bbadfc5d42
Depends-On: Ia5bddfc5e2fd77cd6e9e855c680b079f78fc1c3f

commit_message:
Redirect all but cobbler and api from port 80

Redirect almost all from port 80 to port 8443 with SSL. Exclusions:
* API still have redirected to port 8000.
* Cobbler still uses port 80.

Change-Id: I872bb1c29df4b4775166944db7941296b352d93c
Closes-Bug: #1497397
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/53/226653/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: RewriteRule ^/$ https://%{HTTP_HOST}:8443%{REQUEST_URI} [R=301,L] RewriteCond %{HTTPS} off

commit_message:
Correct instance parameter description

get_node_by_instance() only support for 'instance uuid', remove
'instance name' to avoid confusion.

Change-Id: Icaebf43c5daeba055b6d6054b1a51f4a51468620

deleted_lines: :param instance: The instance name or uuid to search for.

commit_message:
Fix LB status updates

This commit updates the health monitor to update the load balancer
status even if the given load balancer (and associated amphorae) do not
have any listeners.

Change-Id: Iedfd9ebcf8e2e948c89cbc584c8fdea921b0cfbd
Closes-Bug: 1544290
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/07/281707/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_update_health_no_listener(self, session): health = { "id": self.FAKE_UUID_1, "listeners": {}} session.return_value = 'blah' lb = mock.MagicMock() lb.operating_status.lower.return_value = 'blah' self.amphora_repo.get.load_balancer_id.return_value = self.FAKE_UUID_1 self.loadbalancer_repo.get.return_value = lb self.hm.update_health(health) self.assertTrue(self.amphora_repo.get.called) self.assertTrue(lb.operating_status.lower.called) self.assertTrue(self.loadbalancer_repo.update.called) @mock.patch('octavia.db.api.get_session')

Add tests for fetching the revocation list

There was no test for fetching the revocation list. A couple of
simple tests are added to improve coverage.

added_lines: class TestFetchRevocationList(test_v3.RestfulTestCase): """Test fetch token revocation list on the v3 Identity API.""" def config_overrides(self): super(TestFetchRevocationList, self).config_overrides() self.config_fixture.config(group='revoke', driver='kvs') self.config_fixture.config(group='token', revoke_by_id=True) def test_ids_no_tokens(self): # When there's no revoked tokens the response is an empty list, and # the response is signed. res = self.get('/auth/tokens/OS-PKI/revoked') signed = res.json['signed'] clear = cms.cms_verify(signed, CONF.signing.certfile, CONF.signing.ca_certs) payload = json.loads(clear) self.assertEqual({'revoked': []}, payload) def test_ids_token(self): # When there's a revoked token, it's in the response, and the response # is signed. token_res = self.v3_create_token( self.build_authentication_request( user_id=self.user['id'], password=self.user['password'], project_id=self.project['id'])) token_id = token_res.headers.get('X-Subject-Token') token_data = token_res.json['token'] self.delete('/auth/tokens', headers={'X-Subject-Token': token_id}) res = self.get('/auth/tokens/OS-PKI/revoked') signed = res.json['signed'] clear = cms.cms_verify(signed, CONF.signing.certfile, CONF.signing.ca_certs) payload = json.loads(clear) def truncate(ts_str): return ts_str[:19] + 'Z' # 2016-01-21T15:53:52 == 19 chars. exp_token_revoke_data = { 'id': token_id, 'audit_id': token_data['audit_ids'][0], 'expires': truncate(token_data['expires_at']), } self.assertEqual({'revoked': [exp_token_revoke_data]}, payload)

commit_message:
3PAR get host by WWN now handles mixed cases

The 3PAR driver comparison of WWNs will be able to handle
WWNs with upper/lower case differences. For example, the
driver code can now locate a 3PAR host with a WWN of
123abc6789012345 or 123ABD6789012345.

Change-Id: I571713f34ec3737123920acdbf20999baccd90b2
Closes-Bug: 1546453

subject: Fix amphora failover after health monitor start
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-18 06:32:58.000000000', 'files': ['octavia/controller/healthmanager/health_manager.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/octavia/commit/042dfd4df746f81db741109f0af528ff3ee29876', 'message': "Fix amphora failover after health monitor start

The health monitor consists of two daemons: One receives heartbeats
from amphorae and updates the database, the other scans the database
for amphorae that haven't checked in in a while. If the health
monitor is down for a while, all the amphorae will seem stale in
the database once it's started again.

This patch changes the behavior of the health_check such that amphorae
have time to check in after the health monitor start before the
health monitor daemon decides they need to be failed over.

Change-Id: I0599d214c645547b3248f73f6bb3380653de0585
Closes-Bug: 1532623
"}]
commit_message:
Fix amphora failover after health monitor start

The health monitor consists of two daemons: One receives heartbeats
from amphorae and updates the database, the other scans the database
for amphorae that haven't checked in in a while. If the health
monitor is down for a while, all the amphorae will seem stale in
the database once it's started again.

This patch changes the behavior of the health_check such that amphorae
have time to check in after the health monitor start before the
health monitor daemon decides they need to be failed over.

Change-Id: I0599d214c645547b3248f73f6bb3380653de0585
Closes-Bug: 1532623
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/60/281660/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Don't start checking immediately, as the health manager may # have been down for a while and amphorae not able to check in. LOG.debug("Pausing before starting health check") time.sleep(CONF.health_manager.heartbeat_timeout) while True: time.sleep(CONF.health_manager.health_check_interval)

subject: Change for synchronous Mistral actions from CLI
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-19 18:47:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/mistral/commit/4a7b13369fb625c6436e89b50eca29f12790a2c2', 'message': "Change for synchronous Mistral actions from CLI

This patch allows the Mistral actions to be run synchronously from
the Mistral CLI.

When a Mistral action is run synchronously using the Mistral CLI
'run-action' command, it does not complete successfully. This is due
to the Mistral API server handling requests on a single thread.

The 'run-action' command performs a REST POST call to the
ActionExecution RestController in the API server. That in turn calls
back into the python-mistralclient which then performs another REST
call back to the appropriate REST controller to actually run the
action requested. That call hangs since the requests are handled on
a single thread because the first POST has not completed yet.
Eventually the RPC call between the engine and the executor servers
times out, and the 'run-action' command fails.

This patch changes the Mistral API server so that requests are
handled in separate threads.

Change-Id: I8e06d3ef6aab4b2009a8fff4aa4d1acc118eee3f
Implements: blueprint mistral-mistral-actions

This patch changes the Mistral API server so that requests are
handled in separate threads.

Added a new functional test to the tempest test package to test
synchronous action execution of a mistral action from within

commit_message:
Change for synchronous Mistral actions from CLI

This patch allows the Mistral actions to be run synchronously from
the Mistral CLI.

When a Mistral action is run synchronously using the Mistral CLI
'run-action' command, it does not complete successfully. This is due
to the Mistral API server handling requests on a single thread.

The 'run-action' command performs a REST POST call to the
ActionExecution RestController in the API server. That in turn calls
back into the python-mistralclient which then performs another REST
call back to the appropriate REST controller to actually run the
action requested. That call hangs since the requests are handled on
a single thread because the first POST has not completed yet.
Eventually the RPC call between the engine and the executor servers
times out, and the 'run-action' command fails.

This patch changes the Mistral API server so that requests are
handled in separate threads.

Added a new functional test to the tempest test package to test
synchronous action execution of a mistral action from within
mistral.

Change-Id: I8e06d3ef6aab4b2009a8fff4aa4d1acc118eee3f
Implements: blueprint mistral-mistral-actions

subject: Fix deleted amphora expiration check
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-18 05:40:25.000000000', 'files': ['octavia/tests/functional/db/test_repositories.py', 'octavia/db/repositories.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/octavia/commit/ab83f5cedde8398f7941de98f29f3cccb867aa82', 'message': 'Fix deleted amphora expiration check

During a normal failover, the housekeeping manager will attempt
to clean up database records having to do with the dead amphora based
on the last health check of said amphora. However, at least some of
the time, the amphora health manager would have already cleaned up
the health record, meaning that the housekeeping manager gets a
None response when it attempts to check the deleted amphora health.
This could lead to a failure in the dead amp cleanup process, possibly
gumming up failover or other tasks along the way.

This commit fixes this check such that if no health record exists
for the deleted amphora, it is assumed the amphora is expired and
all record of it can be deleted from the database.

Change-Id: Icded7127d7817d8c71a5fcb90c95775a2bf5f58c
Closes-Bug: 1544427
'}]
commit_message:
Fix deleted amphora expiration check

During a normal failover, the housekeeping manager will attempt
to clean up database records having to do with the dead amphora based
on the last health check of said amphora. However, at least some of
the time, the amphora health manager would have already cleaned up
the health record, meaning that the housekeeping manager gets a
None response when it attempts to check the deleted amphora health.
This could lead to a failure in the dead amp cleanup process, possibly
gumming up failover or other tasks along the way.

This commit fixes this check such that if no health record exists
for the deleted amphora, it is assumed the amphora is expired and
all record of it can be deleted from the database.

Change-Id: Icded7127d7817d8c71a5fcb90c95775a2bf5f58c
Closes-Bug: 1544427

commit_message:
invert the order of endpoint and bind_service attributes

* endpoint type (admin, internal, public) and service (identitiy, network etc.)
  was switched during refactoring, this patch reverts this unintended switching
* edited bind_service service type from public,internal,admin to 'all'
  for default binding to just one service

Change-Id: I9bf230ba53d23ce11a32acaea2410572eaeb6123
Depends-On: Iec485deaf415e4187a323435cce2b6bbadfc5d42
Depends-On: Ia5bddfc5e2fd77cd6e9e855c680b079f78fc1c3f

commit_message:
Update nova-neutron configuration

Our current nova-neutron configuration does not work with
the latest puppet-nova. In particular, this patch[1].

We also were not using hieradata for the configuration,
so this patch resolves that as well.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/puppet-nova/commit/d09868a59c451932d67c66101b725182d7066a14

Change-Id: I8b6d907fe46579007f33a7e69e7d67e79582426c

commit_message:
Ignore errors on old properties during update

When an update fails on a template resource, we still store the template
in the stack environment. Retrying the update will fail because of
missing parameters, but we can ignore those as they should be harmless
and only matter in this broken case.

Change-Id: I859ea72b1cc95162b6f498b6af65e4d9fdd9458f
Closes-Bug: #1543685

commit_message:
Add a request timeout to the REST API driver

The amphora REST driver does not have reasonable timeouts on the
python "requests" library calls. For example, the PUT call to
load a certificate into an amphora can hang forever.
This patch adds a request timeout that defaults to 5 seconds.

Change-Id: I75bed9fa1d590ce206aa0947d35552fc80907c0a
Closes-Bug: #1496634

commit_message:
Fix health monitor URL in API documentation

After looking into bug reports of health monitor URLs not
working after the shared pools patch, I was able to verify that
they do in fact work, but that the legacy documentation was wrong.
(This is after checking both the state of Octavia's documentation
and API code prior to the shared pools patch, and checking the
neutron-lbaas octavia driver in master right now.)

This patch updates the octavia API documentation to list the
correct new and legacy URLs for doing health monitor CRUD operations.

Change-Id: I632a0a50de0320ed316ef0bf180b8d7e788f746a
Closes-Bug: 1543364
Closes-Bug: 1543366

commit_message:
Delete workflow members when deleting workflow

Workflow owner can not delete a shared workflow if it has been used to
create cron-triggers by the shared member.

Implements: blueprint mistral-workflow-resource-sharing
Change-Id: I063716f081085fda53c9ef3a871cffb570498161
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/48/282648/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_owner_delete_shared_workflow(self): wf = db_api.create_workflow_definition(WF_DEFINITIONS[1]) workflow_sharing = { 'resource_id': wf.id, 'resource_type': 'workflow', 'project_id': security.get_project_id(), 'member_id': user_context.project_id, 'status': 'pending', } db_api.create_resource_member(workflow_sharing) # Switch to another tenant, accept the sharing. auth_context.set_ctx(user_context) db_api.update_resource_member( wf.id, 'workflow', user_context.project_id, {'status': 'accepted'} ) fetched = db_api.get_workflow_definition(wf.id) self.assertEqual(wf, fetched) # Switch to original tenant, delete the workflow. auth_context.set_ctx(test_base.get_context()) db_api.delete_workflow_definition(wf.id) # Switch to another tenant, can not see that workflow. auth_context.set_ctx(user_context) self.assertRaises( exc.NotFoundException, db_api.get_workflow_definition, wf.id ) def test_owner_delete_shared_workflow_has_crontrigger(self): wf = db_api.create_workflow_definition(WF_DEFINITIONS[1]) workflow_sharing = { 'resource_id': wf.id, 'resource_type': 'workflow', 'project_id': security.get_project_id(), 'member_id': user_context.project_id, 'status': 'pending', } db_api.create_resource_member(workflow_sharing) # Switch to another tenant, accept the sharing. auth_context.set_ctx(user_context) db_api.update_resource_member( wf.id, 'workflow', user_context.project_id, {'status': 'accepted'} ) # Create cron trigger using the shared workflow. CRON_TRIGGERS[0]['workflow_id'] = wf.id db_api.create_cron_trigger(CRON_TRIGGERS[0]) # Switch to original tenant, try to delete the workflow. auth_context.set_ctx(test_base.get_context()) self.assertRaises( exc.DBException, db_api.delete_workflow_definition, wf.id )

commit_message:
Allocate separate partition for Horizon uploads

By default horizon firstly uploads image to /tmp directory
and pushes it to glance then. Sometimes a lack of free space
in /tmp dir may cause cluster going offline.

Change-Id: I7cb9edd3f6a31b86696d708c525cf8d031642c58
DocImpact: Add information that uploads to Horizon are limited to 11Gb
Partial-Bug: #1496838

Add initial spec file for oslo.config

Change-Id: I0e4ddb5304b64a11554510b28d98f6a6d23ed2e3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rpm-packaging refs/changes/93/270493/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: %global sname oslo.config Name: {{ 'oslo.config' | py2pkg }} Epoch: 2 Version: 2.4.0 Release: 0 Summary: OpenStack common configuration library Group: Development/Languages License: {{ 'Apache-2.0' | license }} Url: https://launchpad.net/%{sname} Source0: https://pypi.python.org/packages/source/o/%{sname}/%{sname}-%{version}.tar.gz BuildRequires: openstack-macros BuildRequires: python-devel BuildRequires: {{ 'disover' | py2pkg }} BuildRequires: {{ 'pbr' | py2pkg }} BuildRequires: {{ 'setuptools' | py2pkg }} BuildRequires: {{ 'testrepository' | py2pkg }} BuildRequires: {{ 'testscenarios' | py2pkg }} >= 0.4 BuildRequires: {{ 'testtools' | py2pkg }} >= 0.9.34 Requires: {{ 'argparse' | py2pkg }} Requires: {{ 'netaddr' | py2pkg }} >= 0.7.12 Requires: {{ 'pbr' | py2pkg }} >= 1.6 Requires: {{ 'setuptools' | py2pkg }} Requires: {{ 'six' | py2pkg }} >= 1.9.0 Requires: {{ 'stevedore' | py2pkg }} >= 1.5.0 BuildArch: noarch Provides: %{name} = %{epoch}:%{version} Obsoletes: %{name} < %{epoch}:%{version} %description The Oslo project intends to produce a python library containing infrastructure code shared by OpenStack projects. The APIs provided by the project should be high quality, stable, consistent and generally useful. The oslo-config library is a command line and configuration file parsing library from the Oslo project. %package doc Summary: Documentation for OpenStack common configuration library Provides: %{name}-doc = %{epoch}:%{version} Obsoletes: %{name}-doc < %{epoch}:%{version} BuildRequires: {{ 'fixtures' | py2pkg }} BuildRequires: {{ 'netaddr' | py2pkg }} BuildRequires: {{ 'oslosphinx' | py2pkg }} >= 2.3.0 BuildRequires: {{ 'Sphinx' | py2pkg }} BuildRequires: {{ 'stevedore' | py2pkg }} BuildRequires: git %description doc Documentation for the oslo-config library. %prep %setup -q -n %{sname}-%{version} %build %{__python2} setup.py build %install %{__python2} setup.py install -O1 --skip-build --root %{buildroot} %{__python2} setup.py build_sphinx # remove the sphinx-build leftovers rm -rf doc/build/html/.{doctrees,buildinfo} %check export PYTHONPATH="%{python2_sitelib}:%{buildroot}%{python2_sitelib}" export PYTHON="python -S" testr init && testr run %files %doc README.rst %license LICENSE %{_bindir}/oslo-config-generator %{python2_sitelib}/oslo_config %{python2_sitelib}/*.egg-info %files doc %doc doc/build/html %license LICENSE %changelog

commit_message:
Remove trove ubuntu package hack

Bug #1365561 has been marked as fixed so it should be safe to remove
hack adding group and file before installing package.

Change-Id: Id447a47a056a41d8c98b01d6769f4121a36d7aae

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-11 03:53:09.000000000', 'files': ['heat/engine/scheduler.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/3c96f5a0843f47ac7b5e43f56f76b65a70e985c9', 'message': 'Fix scheduler compatibility with Python 3.7 harder

Always catch StopIteration, rather than allowing it to bubble up a level.
This is neccessary due to PEP0479, wherein it was decided that Python will
start converting this exception to a RuntimeError when it bubbles up,
beginning with Python 3.7.

This is a follow-up to f7edd0ba2d3354e57c106e20ad88c50a859db592, which
missed one case of where StopIteration could be raised.

Change-Id: I34bc32e7477bcaa0ddfe30179f1008b1be97c0a3
'}]
commit_message:
Fix scheduler compatibility with Python 3.7 harder

Always catch StopIteration, rather than allowing it to bubble up a level.
This is neccessary due to PEP0479, wherein it was decided that Python will
start converting this exception to a RuntimeError when it bubbles up,
beginning with Python 3.7.

This is a follow-up to f7edd0ba2d3354e57c106e20ad88c50a859db592, which
missed one case of where StopIteration could be raised.

Change-Id: I34bc32e7477bcaa0ddfe30179f1008b1be97c0a3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/54/278854/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: subtask = parent.throw(*sys.exc_info()) except StopIteration: return

commit_message:
Handle redirects for Horizon

As for Heat, we need to be able to handle 30X redirects from Horizon
when configured to use SSL.  Because Horizon's redirects are
handled directly by Apache, we can't use middleware to handle the
X-Forwarded-Proto header like we are planning to do for the other
services.  However, in this case we don't need to worry about
rewriting urls in the payload like we do for the other services
because Horizon is just serving standard web pages, not custom
HTTP bodies with JSON contents.

One other change from the previous Heat patch is to drop the IP
from the rewrite regex.  This is because Horizon will generally be
accessed via a DNS name, so the IP won't appear in the Location
header.  The heat regex should probably be changed as well since
we now support registering endpoints with DNS names, but since we
plan to move all the other services to the X-Forwarded-Proto header
middleware anyway we can probably just wait until that happens and
then remove the Heat rule entirely.

Change-Id: I039a3036be17eeabe3cff68e0ef24f70907cc568
(cherry picked from commit 55b24a306d8ab6f71fa2b82f49d928dc72f8a3b0)

commit_message:
Add test to check category-show error message

Test case check that error message after calling category-show with non
existing category name contains user friendly substring

Targets: blueprint murano-cli-integration-test-coverage

Change-Id: I4c7b031d5c602b39962c8b0081c8e416718335dc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-muranoclient refs/changes/66/281366/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_non_existing_category_show(self): """Test scenario: 1) try to call category-show for non existing category 2) check that error message contains user friendly substring """ exc = self.assertRaises(Exception, self.murano, 'category-show', params='non-existing') self.assertIn("Category id 'non-existing' not found", exc.stdout)

subject: packages: secure upgrade workflow from dependency cycles
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-18 13:23:06.000000000', 'files': ['spec/classes/tripleo_packages_spec.rb', 'manifests/packages.pp'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo/commit/e8c744ba85b161291f9daedd56f9a6cbf85ab5d4', 'message': 'packages: secure upgrade workflow from dependency cycles

Change the workflow to be:
Upgrade all packages before any services that is notified & managed by
Puppet.
It also disable the Exec timeout so we rely on Heat timeout and not on
the 300s that are the default in Puppet [1]

Example: we upgrade and OpenStack config will change (obviously).
         Puppet catalog will contain 3 important things:
           * config resources
           * service resources
           * package-upgrade Exec resource
         with that patch, what will happen:
           * puppet will update config first or second and notify
             services
           * puppet will run package-upgrade first or second but before
             the package-upgrade Exec resource
           * at the very end, puppet will restart services

That way, we avoid complications with Puppet dependency cycle issues.

[1] https://docs.puppetlabs.com/references/latest/type.html#exec-attribute-timeout

Closes-Bug: 1536349
Change-Id: I07310bdfc5b07b03ac9fa5f8c13e87eaa2bfef4d
(cherry picked from commit 0543b4de44c36fcb351b127fa0c0d0c35d17965f)
'}]
commit_message:
packages: secure upgrade workflow from dependency cycles

Change the workflow to be:
Upgrade all packages before any services that is notified & managed by
Puppet.
It also disable the Exec timeout so we rely on Heat timeout and not on
the 300s that are the default in Puppet [1]

Example: we upgrade and OpenStack config will change (obviously).
         Puppet catalog will contain 3 important things:
           * config resources
           * service resources
           * package-upgrade Exec resource
         with that patch, what will happen:
           * puppet will update config first or second and notify
             services
           * puppet will run package-upgrade first or second but before
             the package-upgrade Exec resource
           * at the very end, puppet will restart services

That way, we avoid complications with Puppet dependency cycle issues.

[1] https://docs.puppetlabs.com/references/latest/type.html#exec-attribute-timeout

Closes-Bug: 1536349
Change-Id: I07310bdfc5b07b03ac9fa5f8c13e87eaa2bfef4d
(cherry picked from commit 0543b4de44c36fcb351b127fa0c0d0c35d17965f)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo refs/changes/46/281846/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: timeout => 0, # 1) Upgrade all packages via exec. # Note: The Package Puppet resources can be managed after or before package-upgrade, # it does not matter. what we need to make sure is that they'll notify their # respective services (if they have ~> in their manifests or here with the ->) # for the other packages, they'll be upgraded before any Service notify. # This approach prevents from Puppet dependencies cycle. # 2) This upgrade will be run before any Service notified & managed by Puppet. # Note: For example, during the Puppet catalog, configuration will change for most of # the services so the Services will be likely restarted after the package upgrade. Exec['package-upgrade'] -> Service <| |>
deleted_lines: # 1) upgrade puppet managed packages (will trigger puppet dependencies) # 2) then upgrade all packages via exec # 3) then restart services Package <| |> -> Exec['package-upgrade'] -> Service <| |>

commit_message:
Use 'type -P' instead of which

Core set of packages might not include command 'which'
in CentOS7.

'type -P' which is a built-in in bash could be used instead.

Change-Id: I27365ff7be973b83f2f3d817660ce8c5952ed887
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/14/251414/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: TIMEOUT_CMD=$(type -P timeout || true)
deleted_lines: _which() { local file_name=$1 IFS=: for path in ${PATH}; do if [[ -x "${path}/${file_name}" ]]; then echo "${path}/${file_name}" return 0 fi done return 1 } TIMEOUT_CMD=$(_which timeout || true)

commit_message:
Increase dockerctl check timeout

Sometimes on hosts with HDD drives we need more time for container
to spin up.

Related-Bug: #1520754

Change-Id: Ibea81e8aa820cc007bc13e4531ea598d81a5129f

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-18 18:19:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/ca5500769c7475a6a957dc8238f3c926773c43de', 'message': "Fix supervisord pid file path

commit_message:
[WIP] Fix supervisord pid file path

By default supervisord uses /var/run/supervisord/supervisord.pid file.
Changing this to a different one through puppet may lead to issues
when supervisorctl cannot work with daemon until the daemon is restarted.

Here is how it works:

* supervisord started before puppet run with default pid file
* puppet modifies supervisord config without restarting it (e.g.
  on CentOS7 it can't be restarted because it may be launched
  as PID 1 process inside a contaiener)
* supervisorctl when called checks config file and using pid
  file checks if daemon is alive. But path to pid file was changed
  and supervisorctl fails.

Blueprint: master-on-centos7

Is NOT compatible with CentOS6 master node

Change-Id: I354ac297831120d9a3f57b970598647fdc1bb6e9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/78/247078/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: file=/var/run/supervisor/supervisor.sockserverurl=unix:///var/run/supervisor/supervisor.sock

commit_message:
[WIP] Swith to centos7

Based on https://review.openstack.org/#/c/232182/1

Change-Id: I6374f4fd9282bcc83daf529f478a3c3e2f553ee3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/26/237526/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ENV DOCKER_PORT _PORT_ADD start.sh /usr/local/bin/ ADD setup.sh /usr/local/bin/ ADD start-container.service /etc/systemd/system/ RUN chmod +x /usr/local/bin/{setup,start}.sh CMD ["/usr/lib/systemd/systemd"]
deleted_lines:
RUN rm -rf /etc/yum.repos.d/*; \ echo -e "\ [nailgun]
\ name=Nailgun Local Repo
\ baseurl=http://$(route -n | awk '/^0.0.0.0/ { print $2 }'):_PORT_/os/x86_64/
\ gpgcheck=0" \ > /etc/yum.repos.d/nailgun.repo; \ yum clean expire-cache; \ yum update -yADD start.sh /usr/local/bin/start.sh RUN mkdir -p /var/log/rabbitmq; \ puppet apply --detailed-exitcodes -d -v \ /etc/puppet/modules/nailgun/examples/rabbitmq-only.pp; \ [[ $? == 0 || $? == 2 ]] RUN echo -e "\ [nailgun]
\ name=Nailgun Local Repo
\ baseurl=file:/var/www/nailgun/centos/x86_64
\ gpgcheck=0" \ > /etc/yum.repos.d/nailgun.repo; \ yum clean all; \ chmod +x /usr/local/bin/start.shCMD /usr/local/bin/start.sh

commit_message:
[WIP] Swith to centos7 (systemd)

Based on https://review.openstack.org/#/c/232182/1

PatchSet 111:
- add 'systemctl daemon-reload' before each puppet apply

PatchSet 114:
- use LVM for docker, based on https://review.openstack.org/#/c/153211

PatchSet 115:
- add missed -c option

PatchSet 116:
- move disable getty and firewalld into kickstart

PatchSet 117:
- move requiretty sudo settings into kickstart
- new mcollective with systemd support

PatchSet 118:
- revert PatchSet 114, it's not ready

Change-Id: Ie45676656ce24b05ece799e6b2340996238092f7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/22/232222/87 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sudo rm -vf $(SANDBOX)/etc/mtab

subject: [WIP] centos 7 support

commit_message:
Use the class param to configure Cinder 'host' setting

By configuring the Cinder 'host' setting via the appropriate class
param instead of cinder_config we don't risk to override it if the
user is to pass additional config settings using cinder_config in
ExtraConfig.

Change-Id: Idf33d87e08355b5b4369ccb0001db8d4c3b4c20f
(cherry picked from commit 3ac244adda7618a0003f0c58ccbba7e3a1ba5f12)

commit_message:
Set 'host' globally in Cinder instead of per-backend basis

This change will set a common value for 'host' across all
controllers. We missed to do so for the NFS backend previously.

It will still be possible to set a different per-backend 'host'
value by providing it via ExtraData.

Change-Id: I00fd05660a15be3611e1a394650be6ab713670f9
(cherry picked from commit fd0b25b010db428c450b99b50ff3a0d60d263005)

commit_message:
Replace all groups enumaration with wildcard

This would eliminate great confusion for Fuel / plugins developers, when
trying to understand long role lists put in many places.

Depends-On: I2f32fe26bf90656b820c21167faa0e35697bc322
Closes-bug: #1538961

to keep the tests running at the gate.

subject: neutron: delete by default router/dhcp namespaces
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-04 09:43:19.000000000', 'files': ['puppet/hieradata/controller.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/8f5afec62374288ad106d85d68b9efe43039383b', 'message': "neutron: delete by default router/dhcp namespaces

The 'router_delete_namespaces' (L3 agent) and 'dhcp_delete_namespaces'
(DHCP agent) configuration settings default to false OpenStack Neutron
resulting in network namespaces not being deleted when
no longer needed. Disabling automatic namespace cleanup was appropriate
for older Linux distributions but is no longer required.
TripleO should set the values to true.

Change-Id: I39e1a347d24ecc99b6f878807c47103c4b3f85e1
(cherry picked from commit e479da3e1780095d8a471cb2fb44ee288c391bb9)
"}]
commit_message:
neutron: delete by default router/dhcp namespaces

The 'router_delete_namespaces' (L3 agent) and 'dhcp_delete_namespaces'
(DHCP agent) configuration settings default to false OpenStack Neutron
resulting in network namespaces not being deleted when
no longer needed. Disabling automatic namespace cleanup was appropriate
for older Linux distributions but is no longer required.
TripleO should set the values to true.

Change-Id: I39e1a347d24ecc99b6f878807c47103c4b3f85e1
(cherry picked from commit e479da3e1780095d8a471cb2fb44ee288c391bb9)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/15/276115/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: neutron::agents::l3::router_delete_namespaces: True neutron::agents::dhcp::dhcp_delete_namespaces: True

Change-Id: Ibe4eaedf986a9077f869c6530381e69ee0281f5b
(cherry picked from commit 9d83200459482e5b31f660fa312b468acfb2da4c)
'}]
commit_message:
Wire the Glance rbd user correctly into the external Ceph template

We were incorrectly wiring the rbd user to the relevant glance
module parameter, making it was impossible to customize the
rbd user when using an external Ceph.

Change-Id: Ibe4eaedf986a9077f869c6530381e69ee0281f5b
(cherry picked from commit 9d83200459482e5b31f660fa312b468acfb2da4c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/92/281292/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: glance::backend::rbd::rbd_store_user: {get_param: CephClientUserName}

commit_message:
Unshelve using the RequestSpec object

Now that we have done this for live-migrate and evacuate, we can modify
the unshelve conductor method to get the RequestSpec.

Partially-Implements: blueprint check-destination-on-migrations

Change-Id: I8d17c7eb908c6aa614744058ed7e483ce6afe27d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/18/281418/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: request_spec = objects.RequestSpec.get_by_instance_uuid( context, instance.uuid) except exception.RequestSpecNotFound: # Some old instances can still have no RequestSpec object attached # to them, we need to support the old way request_spec = None self.compute_task_api.unshelve_instance(context, instance, request_spec)

commit_message:
Align template defaults with the client

This aligns the parameter default values from python-tripleoclient
with tripleo-heat-templates. This is in preparation for removing
all the defaults from the client, and maintaining them only in the
templates.

Change-Id: I7b635a250f1ecc170e18d8e434f0118c6fcbb942
Co-Authored-By: James Slagle <jslagle@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 4ff84638ab1fd39b6c907ed2899227462da358cf)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/08/264208/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: default: 'datacentre:1:1000' default: kvm

commit_message:
Last 6-th group of "nightly" functional ui tests for fuel-web.
Update for "Nodes across environment" test group.

"Settings Tab Segment" test group:
  Check "General" segment
  Check "Security" segment
  Check "Compute" segment
  Check "Storage" segment
  Check "Logging" segment
  Check "OpenStack Services" segment
  Check "Other" segment
  User returns to the selected segment on "Settings" tab
  No "Node network group" item via sorting, filtering for unallocated nodes
  Check node roles edition

Change-Id: I35fa39339562efb715a54634da77754de4fb2c08

commit_message:
Add test to check list of existing categories

This test check existing of list and presence of Web and Databases
categories in list

Targets: blueprint murano-ui-integration-test-coverage

Change-Id: I6374363a890d0672ee5e4da19bc28b94c9ed1b49
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-dashboard refs/changes/05/281205/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_list_of_existing_categories(self): """Checks that list of categories avaliable Scenario: 1. Navigate to 'Applications' page 2. Check that list of categories available and basic categories ("Web", "Databases") are present in the list """ self.go_to_submenu('Categories') categories_table_locator = (by.By.CSS_SELECTOR, "table#categories") self.check_element_on_page(*categories_table_locator) for category in ("Databases", "Web"): category_locator = (by.By.XPATH, "//tr[@data-display='{}']".format(category)) self.check_element_on_page(*category_locator)

commit_message:
Remove usage of WritableLogger from oslo_log

With Eventlet 0.17.2, we can directly pass the logger instance. This
allows us to deprecate/remove the WritableLogger class from oslo.log.

So there is no need to maintain class `WritableLogger` in our code.

Change-Id: Ibeedb65ebfb0cd8bc0ffe24069b390931d8dfe4b
Closes-Bug: #1440773
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/23/283023/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: log=self._logger, log=self._logger,
deleted_lines: class WritableLogger(object): """A thin wrapper that responds to `write` and logs.""" def __init__(self, LOG, level=logging.DEBUG): self.LOG = LOG self.level = level def write(self, msg): self.LOG.log(self.level, msg.rstrip("\n")) self._wsgi_logger = WritableLogger(self._logger) log=self._wsgi_logger, log=self._wsgi_logger,

commit_message:
Fix attr error in vip_reservation_plugin

* Add usage of fbp_copy_plugin() method
* Replace usage of method update_yaml_in_container to fpb.change_remote_yaml()
* Update metadata.yaml to become compatible with mitaka-9.0
* Add show_step() usage

Change-Id: Id1fa4dc6fb2b67351db3a2f139e509b23f0526bc
Related-Bug: #1548340
Related-Bug: #1548348

commit_message:
devstack fails using magnum plugin

Magnum plugin will make directoy by SCREEN_LOGDIR variable, but this
variable is depend on user environment settings. Besides this variable
had been comment in magnum's default devstack settings. Therefore we
only need to make folder if user had set this variable.

Change-Id: Ife49eb7eab91c98bfb060e67b49b42f00931ec6c
Closes-Bug: 1548118
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/06/284006/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [[ -n ${SCREEN_LOGDIR} ]]; then mkdir -p $SCREEN_LOGDIR fi

commit_message:
Mark 'replacement_policy' as deprecated

The property 'replacement_policy' used to work around
flawed nova/neutron port interaction which has been
fixed since Liberty. Now we can mark it as deprecated
to avoid to replacement port without property change.

Closes-Bug #1530043

Change-Id: I2bc80a8479ad62dba09659fe5eea3f771529e1ab

commit_message:
Add note about using OS-EXT-* prefix for attribute naming

The 2.3 microversion used the OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR prefix for
compat with v2.0 for the ec2 API split out of nova.

The 2.16 microversion added the 'host_status' extended
server attribute and doesn't use the prefix.

This adds a note that nothing after the 2.3 microversion
should be using the OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR prefix since it's an
artifact of v2.0 and extensions which are deprecated in
v2.1.

Similar notes are added for other extensions that add
extended attribute names to other resources like AZs,
volumes and images.

Change-Id: I60a53e13121b7280a41c3889ba86edcd2ae7bf83
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/97/283797/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(mriedem): These will use the OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR prefix below # and that's OK for microversion 2.3 which is being compatible # with v2.0 for the ec2 API split out from Nova. After this, # however, new microversoins should not be using the # OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR prefix. # NOTE(mriedem): Nothing after microversion 2.3 should use the # OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR prefix for the attribute key name.

subject: Fix incorrect assumption when deleting assignments
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-20 16:16:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/e33322e5c69a32ebe31038bd8ba9a42397a392b3', 'message': 'Fix incorrect assumption when deleting assignments

The methods delete_user_assignments() and delete_group_assignments()
in the assignment backend remove all assignments for a user/group -
although the code fails to set the type of assignment and just uses
actor_id, making an assumption that user_id != group_id.

This patch specifies the type of assignments in the delete (i.e
USER_PROJECT/USER_DOMAIN or GROUP_PROJECT/GROUP_DOMAIN) to make sure
no assignment will be mistakenly deleted.

Change-Id: I246a61a291dd41490f49b7b26a04f93e69e61d7a
Closes-Bug: #1440135
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-02-23 03:24:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/9eb3c0582d962d40693f4911453c3f7d197b0ed0', 'message': 'Fix incorrect assumption when deleting assignments

The methods delete_user_assignments() and delete_group_assignments()
in the assignment backend remove all assignments for a user/group -
although the code fails to set the type of assignment and just uses
actor_id, making an assumption that user_id != group_id.

This patch specifies the type of assignments in the delete (i.e
USER_PROJECT/USER_DOMAIN or GROUP_PROJECT/GROUP_DOMAIN) to make sure
no assignment will be mistakenly deleted.

Change-Id: I246a61a291dd41490f49b7b26a04f93e69e61d7a
Closes-Bug: #1440135
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-02-24 01:07:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/7cffd2ebb440e1df00a60f38b70d0832605927b1', 'message': 'Fix incorrect assumption when deleting assignments

The methods delete_user_assignments() and delete_group_assignments()
in the assignment backend remove all assignments for a user/group -
although the code fails to set the type of assignment and just uses
actor_id, making an assumption that user_id != group_id.

This patch specifies the type of assignments in the delete (i.e
USER_PROJECT/USER_DOMAIN or GROUP_PROJECT/GROUP_DOMAIN) to make sure
no assignment will be mistakenly deleted.

Change-Id: I246a61a291dd41490f49b7b26a04f93e69e61d7a
Closes-Bug: #1440135
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2016-02-24 03:11:03.000000000', 'files': ['keystone/assignment/backends/sql.py', 'keystone/tests/unit/backend/legacy_drivers/assignment/V8/sql.py', 'keystone/tests/unit/test_backend.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/809e5533ccdbffcc73ef9c6bda158e7f8386bb08', 'message': 'Fix incorrect assumption when deleting assignments

The methods delete_user_assignments() and delete_group_assignments()
in the assignment backend remove all assignments for a user/group -
although the code fails to set the type of assignment and just uses
actor_id, making an assumption that user_id != group_id.

This patch specifies the type of assignments in the delete (i.e
USER_PROJECT/USER_DOMAIN or GROUP_PROJECT/GROUP_DOMAIN) to make sure
no assignment will be mistakenly deleted.

Change-Id: I246a61a291dd41490f49b7b26a04f93e69e61d7a
Closes-Bug: #1440135
'}]
commit_message:
Fix incorrect assumption when deleting assignments

The methods delete_user_assignments() and delete_group_assignments()
in the assignment backend remove all assignments for a user/group -
although the code fails to set the type of assignment and just uses
actor_id, making an assumption that user_id != group_id.

This patch specifies the type of assignments in the delete (i.e
USER_PROJECT/USER_DOMAIN or GROUP_PROJECT/GROUP_DOMAIN) to make sure
no assignment will be mistakenly deleted.

Change-Id: I246a61a291dd41490f49b7b26a04f93e69e61d7a
Closes-Bug: #1440135

commit_message:
fix SSL/TLS warnings in build

The specs build talks to Launchpad to ensure that there is a blueprint
for each spec being added to the repository. Those calls emit warnings
unless SSL is configured properly, which requires newer SSL libraries
than are available in the standard library.

Change-Id: I86f8af6ec1f890ebdd260226b0323df8040405a4
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

subject: Added #nosec for bandit check
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-24 00:38:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/sahara/commit/b2c47c8c13ebe27296b3dc8e2df0a22c57e464df', 'message': 'Added #nosec for bandit check

The MySQL class in the sahara.plugins.mapr.services.mysql.mysql
module contains several class level variables that contain
templated strings for performing SQL functions. One of these,
the GET_USERS_HOSTS entry, contains an SQL command with a
string variable for the user name involved in the query.
This string causes bandit to flag this module for security review.
The templated string properly quotes the variable being substituted
and is not used in a manner which exposes it to injection style
attacks.

The line with the definition for GET_USERS_HOSTS should be marked
with the "# nosec" comment as per the bandit documentation to
avoid having it be reported during the gate test.

Change-Id: I9b18c6ed5ada636350c8dc2b4d5ea1869750caa4

commit_message:
Change the SERVICE_TENANT_NAME to SERVICE_PROJECT_NAME

The intergation test job has been broken, it seems because the replace
TENANT => PROJECT change in devstack scrpts, see[1]. This patch change the
SERVICE_TENANT_NAME to SERVICE_PROJECT_NAME in devstack plugin.

And to avoid with aodh change, this change temporarily skip the
gabbits-live test.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/281779/

Closes-Bug: #1548634
Change-Id: Ibb1f78d47311117f6718707c5961bc2841473924

commit_message:
Versioned Object Compatibility Mode

The following proposal is to enable rolling upgrades within Ceilometer.

bp object-compatibility-mode

Change-Id: I2f3264ad8576e1e282b0e382ff5a3f4affb04e78
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/42/197942/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================== Versioned Object Compatibility Mode =================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/object-compatibility-mode The following proposal is to enable rolling upgrades in Ceilometer. More specifically, it allows Ceilometer services to be updated one at a time in a running cluster - the cluster is operational while the upgrade is taking place. It follows the rolling upgrade feature in Nova, using oslo.versionedobjects, but is different in that there is no conductor, which takes on the role of backporting objects to a supported version. Instead, RPC versions and objects are going to be pinned to a backwards compatible version and later switched to the latest version when all the services are upgraded. Problem description =================== Right now, when a new milestone is released, it can take quite a while to upgrade all the services within an OpenStack cloud to the latest release. Upgrade involves syncing the database to the latest schema and updating each distributed Ceilometer service. This process can take down the whole service for a significant time duration. Operators want to reduce the downtime for their cloud when upgrading to the next release. See also some Versioned Objects background in the original proposal: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ObjectProposal Proposed change =============== There are a couple of problems with upgrading a distributed service such as Ceilometer: 1. The content sent over RPC can change. 2. The RPC interface itself can change, i.e. new keyword arguments can be added. The implementation is as follows: To address these problems, the content can be made backwards compatible using oslo.versionedobjects, and the RPC interface can be pinned to a specific version until all components within Ceilometer are upgraded. 1. Define one version for every versionedobjects object we use. Just simply put it into base versionedobject class: class CeilometerObject: VERSION = 1.0 Each time an object which inherits from this one is changed, the version is bumped up on this variable. 2. We introduce new a config option in ceilometer.conf combatibility_mode = 1.4 3. Implement a mechanism which will automatically backport each outgoing message to 1.4 as long as we have this configuration in place. As a result, the version of objects sent through RPC can be "pinned" to a previous version. The compatibility mode version will be cached in memory. A command should be provided to re-read the configuration or to set the compatibility mode version. Each service's rpcapi.py, will set the correct keyword arguments for a given RPC version. Versioned objects sent through RPC will set the correct attributes for a given target version by a a call to their obj_make_compatible() methods, which transform the object to a given target version. Upgrade from the (example) 1.4 version goes through the following path: 1. All nodes are using the 1.4 version 2. A new version is incrementally run with 1.4 compatibility mode 3. When all nodes are already up-to-date, the compatibility mode is incrementally turned off. Once the RPC compatibility mode is added, rolling upgrades should be supported (hopefully in the Liberty release and onwards). Rolling upgrade should be limited to one or two releases backward. When a host/service is too old, it should raise an exception on startup and not be allowed to start. Aliases for OpenStack versions should be provided, to make the upgrade process the same as in nova: http://www.danplanet.com/blog/2015/06/26/upgrading-nova-to-kilo-with-minimal-downtime/ Alternatives ------------ The upgrade process can be left as-is, where all the components must be taken down and upgraded at the same time. Some cloud operators, e.g. Rackspace, have automated their upgrade procedure to a few minutes. However, other cloud operators have a need for this feature. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Pipeline impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- Any new changes to the RPC interfaces would have to add to the backwards compatible layer from when this feature merges and onwards. Also, any new changes to an object (e.g. Alarm) must be made backwards compatible in the object's obj_make_compatible() method. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: kamil-rykowski Work Items ---------- * Create the VERSION variable in base versionedobject class, add documentation and doc-strings in each object, to start documenting changes in their versions * Introduce a new config option in ceilometer.conf * Implement the backporting mechanism * Create a CLI command to switch each Ceilometer service to use a specific compatibility version without restart Future lifecycle ================ None Dependencies ============ * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/versioned-objects Testing ======= Ideally, there should be a rolling upgrade test within tempest (e.g. grenade) to test basic RPC and object pinning between different releases. However, such testing would only apply to release M and onwards because versionedobjects haven't been a part of Ceilometer in the previous releases. Documentation Impact ==================== It should be documented that operators can upgrade Ceilometer components individually, without taking down the entire cloud. References ========== None

commit_message:
Use oslo-versioned-objects to deal with upgrades

Improve the way how the rolling upgrades (updates with no downtime) are
performed in Ceilometer.

bp versioned-objects

Change-Id: If5e5f37fee7ae10107ee2a0f6f3f19ed3aed0b5f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/27/172427/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================ Ceilometer Versioned Objects ============================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/versioned-objects Introduce objects into Ceilometer. An object is used to bundle data with methods that can operate on them. By implementing this spec, we would be able to pass rich objects over RPC and decouple the database schema implementation from SQLAlchemy. Problem description =================== We are looking to improve the way we deal with versioning (of all sorts db/rpc/rest/templates/plugins). Nova has come up with the idea of versioned objects, that Ironic has also now used. This has now been proposed as an oslo library: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/127532/ Versioned-objects will help us deal with DB schema being at a different version than the code expects. This will allow Ceilometer to be operated safely during upgrades. Proposed change =============== There is an approved proposal to put nova.objects into oslo as oslo.versionedobjects - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/127532/ - which would abstract versionable internal objects. The plan is to adopt oslo.versionedobjects and abstract every DB model in Ceilometer. The proposed changes are: * Create a directory ceilometer/objects/ that will contain wrapper objects which are a layer above the DB objects. * Objects will be database schema independent. * Objects will be versioned, allowing older objects to be detected and taking appropriate actions when the objects are incompatible, i.e. fail gracefully or emulate older behavior. * To handle cases where the underlying alarm, meter, resource, sample, etc. could have been changed when the object is in flight, additional arguments (e.g. expected_alarm_state or just expected_state) would be included in the object save method, which would check against the in-database copy of the alarm, meter, resource, sample and others before updates are made and fail gracefully or appropriately sync up the data. Once the objects are in place the rest of the code will be changed to use the versioned objects instead of the db_api directly. This can be done object-by-object to avoid overly large changes. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None. Versioned objects provide an abstraction layer in Ceilometer, allowing for database schema independence. These objects are a replacement for SQLAlchemy objects that are being used to represent db models throughout Ceilometer internals. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Pipeline impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- Unknown. There might be a minor hit in performance since SQLAlchemy objects are abstracted into Ceilometer objects. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- Today, direct database calls are made to create, read, update, and delete resources within Ceilometer. With the switch to an object model, these calls will be made against the appropriate object methods. It will take some time to convert Ceilometer internals over to the object model, so the existing convention of direct database calls should be accepted until all object models are in place. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: kamil-rykowski Work Items ---------- * Implement the objects for each DB object type we have. * Update code that uses the DB to use versioned-objects instead. * Write some developer docs on how to deal with older schema. Future lifecycle ================ The goal of this spec is to introduce versioned objects for every existing model in a single release cycle. When a new resource will be created within Ceilometer, the corresponding implementation for objects should be also provided by the creator of the resource. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= By introducing objects, we are not changing the end user facing API or functionality of Ceilometer. We are passing objects over RPC instead of ids. Given this, no new tempest tests will be created. However, relevant unit tests will be created to test the new object code base. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== * oslo-specs: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/127532/

Use oslo-versioned-objects to deal with upgrades

Improve the way how the rolling upgrades (updates with no downtime) are
performed in Keystone.

This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Keystone Versioned Objects ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/versioned-objects The goal of this spec is to introduce objects into Keystone. An object is used to bundle data with methods that can operate on them. By implementing this spec, we would be able to decouple the database schema implementation from SQLAlchemy. Problem description =================== We are looking to improve the way we deal with versioning (of all sorts db/rpc/rest/templates/plugins). Nova has come up with the idea of versioned objects, that Ironic has also now used. This has now been proposed as an oslo library: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/127532/ Versioned-objects will help us deal with DB schema being at a different version than the code expects. This will allow Keystone to be operated safely during upgrades. Proposed change =============== There is an approved proposal to put nova.objects into oslo as oslo.versionedobjects - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/127532/ - which would abstract versionable internal objects. The plan is to adopt oslo.versionedobjects and abstract every DB model in Keystone. The proposed changes are: * Objects will be database schema independent. * Objects will be versioned, allowing older objects to be detected and taking appropriate actions when the objects are incompatible, i.e. fail gracefully or emulate older behavior. * To handle cases where the underlying user, project, group etc. could have been changed when the object is in flight, additional arguments (e.g. expected_user_state and expected_group_state) would be included in the object save method, which would check against the in-database copy of the object before updates are made and fail gracefully or appropriately sync up the data. Once the objects are in place the rest of the code will be changed to use the versioned objects instead of the db_api directly. This can be done object-by-object to avoid overly large changes. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None. Versioned objects provide an abstraction layer in Keystone, allowing for database schema independence. These objects are a replacement for SQLAlchemy objects that are being used to represent various Keystone resources. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Unknown. There might be a minor hit in performance since SQLAlchemy objects are abstracted into Keystone objects. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- Today, direct database calls are made to create, read, update, and delete resources within Keystone. With the switch to an object model, these calls will be made against the appropriate object methods. It will take some time to convert Keystone internals over to the object model, so the existing convention of direct database calls should be accepted until all object models are in place. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: kamil-rykowski Other contributors: Any help is welcome Work Items ---------- * Implement the objects for each DB object type we have. * Update code that uses the DB to use versioned-objects instead. * Write some developer docs on how to deal with older schema. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= By introducing objects, we are not changing the end user facing API or functionality of Keystone. Given this, no new tempest tests will be created. However, relevant unit tests will be created to test the new object code base is working correctly. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== * oslo-specs: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/127532/

commit_message:
Move test from test_glusterfs and test_quobyte to test_remotefs

 Move unit test for create_cloned_volume from test_glusterfs
 and test_quobyte to test_remotefs, because it checks only
 code, located in remotefs.py file.

 This patch is needed to simplify moving to versionedobjects.

 Change-Id: I661ef85755e9c75aaedb4f157165d2514de3e9ec

Change-Id: I6d7da313feded383022f7b1b3090e7f767e98617

commit_message:
Static physical configuration documentation

Change-Id: I570dcd74fe8bb17009900a604c3133f376b47561
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/vitrage refs/changes/70/283970/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ==================================== Static Physical Plugin Configuration ==================================== Configure Access to Static Physical ----------------------------------- The following should be set in **/etc/vitrage/vitrage.conf**, under synchronizer_plugins section: +----------------------+------------------------------------+--------------------------------+ | Name | Description | Default Value | +======================+====================================+================================+ | static_plugins_dir | Directory path from where to load | /etc/vitrage/static_plugins/ | | | the configurations | | +----------------------+------------------------------------+--------------------------------+ Configure Static Physical Mapping --------------------------------- Physical configuration is made for configuring statically physical entities, and their relationships to other entities in the topology. Some physical entities, such as switches, can not be retrieved from OpenStack, so for now we will configure them statically. There may be more than one configuration file. All files will be read from ... **Format** :: entities: - name: <Physical entity name as appears in configuration> id: <Physical entity id as appears in configuration> type: <Physical entity type - must be from constants.EntityType> state: <resource state> relationships: - type: <Physical entity type it is connected to - must be from constants.EntityType> name: <Physical entity name connected to as appears in configuration> id: <Physical entity id connected to as appears in configuration> relation_type: <Relation name> - type: <Physical entity type it is connected to - must be from constants.EntityType> name: <Physical entity name connected to as appears in configuration> id: <Physical entity id connected to as appears in configuration> relation_type: <Relation name> ... **Example** The following will define a switch that is attached to host-1 and is a backup of switch-2 :: entities: - type: switch name: switch-1 id: 11111 state: available relationships: - type: nova.host name: host-1 id: 22222 relation_type: attached - type: switch name: switch-2 id: 33333 relation_type: backup

commit_message:
Do not offer DHCP leases to unknown machines when using inventory_dhcp

Turns out the dhcp-range option of dnsmasq does not constrain
the DHCP leases to the range specified.
When using inventory_dhcp, we specify the *exact* set of machines
that will be managed by dnsmasq via the json inventory and therefore
it should just provide IPs to those machines.

Change-Id: Ic72ab075a1e2ef351f5ddb00c1a34e5fbb163036

commit_message:
Use yaml.safe_dump instead of yaml.dump

After changing to use yaml.safe_load, some of the tests are failing
locally with unicode error. Though we've not noticed these issues
at the gate, it's better to use safe_dump to avoid them.

Change-Id: I84cf921afe76b3bed44e84230a71b244bb886cce
Closes-Bug: #1547399

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-22 09:03:02.000000000', 'files': ['octavia/tests/functional/db/test_repositories.py', 'octavia/amphorae/drivers/keepalived/vrrp_rest_driver.py', 'octavia/certificates/common/barbican.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/octavia/commit/2c50fd66f5e8c0fd5d3ef8324595b50a8ed28569', 'message': 'Trivial: cleanup unused conf and log variables

In some files, oslo_config.cfg and oslo_log.log  has been imported
but not used. So remove them.

I noticed that there are a lot of unused conf variables in nova and
there is a patch to clean them up:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/280068/
So I wondered if this was a thing in octavia as well.
Turns out it is. :- )

Change-Id: I59b3dcef9143db2dbaae0c9c51f4e098ddcc16e3
'}]
commit_message:
Trivial: cleanup unused conf and log variables

Basic clean up work.
In some files, oslo_config.cfg and oslo_log.log  has been imported
but not used. So remove them.

I noticed that there are a lot of unused conf variables in nova and
there is a patch to clean them up:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/280068/
So I wondered if this was a thing in octavia as well.
Turns out it is. :- )

If have to say why not keeping them, I think it should be making
code clean and avoiding redundant compilation.

Change-Id: I59b3dcef9143db2dbaae0c9c51f4e098ddcc16e3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/07/283007/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix the gate error

If a bay is already deleted, we should delete it in tearDownClass.

Change-Id: I5b7ad89df4f57e1520c07592feb1e554d13e2f2b
Closes-Bug: #1548231

commit_message:
Fix setting the multipath_id

This fixes the logic in how we set the multipath_id in the device_info.
If the returned multipath_id is None, we didn't find a multipath device
and we don't set the multipath_id.  This is exactly what we do for FC.

Change-Id: Ic1f598da59ccda634b765d65706e02d1a4caff30
Closes-Bug: #1547539

commit_message:
Fix XtremIO multi cluster support

* By default all client4 calls are routed to API V2
* renamed request_typ to a clearer parameter name "method"

liberty-backport-potential

Change-Id: I2d4a0cb7caeec5377e623ae4e431cfb57d5a1fce
Closes-Bug: #1538984

commit_message:
Change the SERVICE_TENANT_NAME to SERVICE_PROJECT_NAME

The intergation test job has been broken, it seems because the replace
TENANT => PROJECT change in devstack scrpts, see[1]. This patch change the
SERVICE_TENANT_NAME to SERVICE_PROJECT_NAME in devstack plugin.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/281779/

Closes-Bug: #1548634
Change-Id: I9c7d1a6d28510e5d42deb4aa0280e8a48f042a4d
Depends-On: Ibb1f78d47311117f6718707c5961bc2841473924
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/aodh refs/changes/35/283435/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: iniset $AODH_CONF service_credentials project_name $SERVICE_PROJECT_NAME

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-24 01:46:01.000000000', 'files': ['swift/common/utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/076134784b4eb1c2e55b28218dc0d64a57795d63', 'message': "Add warn method back to LogAdapter

The change in 684c4c04 to improve py3 support breaks older middleware
that consumes the SwiftLogger.

Good for Swift code to not to use warn because it's deprecated.

Bad for LogAdapter to not faithfully provide the current python logging
module API (deprecated or otherwise).

Change-Id: Ib0baf66b7f33f91562867076ff0526a287d8e5a6
"}]
commit_message:
Add warn method back to LogAdapter

The change in 684c4c04 to improve py3 support breaks older middleware
that consumes the SwiftLogger.

Good for Swift code to not to use warn because it's deprecated.

Bad for LogAdapter to not faithfully provide the current python logging
module API (deprecated or otherwise).

Change-Id: Ib0baf66b7f33f91562867076ff0526a287d8e5a6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/01/283901/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.warn = self.warning

commit_message:
Refactor network AZ exception handling

Exceptions that occur while getting network availability zones
should not be masked as if the extension does not exist.

Change-Id: I07213ec6c4d83e97261b58bf8d42417c1cdfae6a
Related-Bug: #1534202

commit_message:
Py3 replace dict.iteritems with six.iteritems

All dict.iteritems in osc are replaced with six.iteritems
except this one.
So fix it to add py3 compatibility.

Change-Id: I1aa51399a36e650d262d839ce2b4ec04d3f91db2

commit_message:
Install language-pack-en for dpkg systems

We add this, because python-swiftclient exposed the dependency issue
between bare-trusy and ubuntu-trusty.

Change-Id: Ide9e2407909cb6e1d7fc571464debe48ed7c53ff
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/51/283851/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: language-pack-en [platform:dpkg]

commit_message:
Shadow users - Separate user identities

"Shadow users: unified identity" implementation:
Separated user identities from their locally managed credentials by
refactoring the user table into user, local_user, and password tables.

user -> local_user -> password
     -> federated_user
     -> ...

(identity) -> (credentials)

Migrated data from the user table to the local_user and password tables.
Modify backend code to utilize the new tables.

Note: #2 "Shadow LDAP and federated users" will be completed in a
different patch. The federated_user table will be added with that patch.

bp shadow-users

Change-Id: I0b6c188824e856d788fe7156e4a9dc2a04cdb6f8

commit_message:
Adds --filter to search for resources

openstack resource list --filter

implements blueprint heat-support-python-openstackclient
implements blueprint heat-stack-resource-search

Change-Id: I9ca33a0743bfad88190509351e8aca08ce7d2c0f
